At the moment i'm not entirely sure how i feel about this game. It is very fun and well made (at time of writing), but i feel that the team who made this game, and the original Rome Total War, is different from the one that made Shogun 2 Total War (my favourite of the franchise). At this stage this is neither a pro or a con, simply an observation.  The game is great, with mechanics resembling those in the earlier games, i.e. Sieges with rams, catapults, etc.. However i feel like some mechanics are missing that could have been utilized, such as the momentum of charges causing troops to penetrate the opposing lines rather than just form a linear front, and individual soldiers having individual fights rather than seemingly mass attacks, both features which were present in Shogun 2, but not in Rome 2.   While some mechanics are missing, this game is still fun nonetheless. Recommended, though i would personally wait for sales to purchase the DLC (or even the base game itself).

On release Creative Assembly was criticized for rushing Total War: Rome II, and like most titles these days it had it's share of bugs. They were significant bugs, mostly from the A.I. that would render the game almost unplayable in certain circumstances. Since then however, Creative Assembly has launched 9 patches and made significant changes to the game requiring another look at it to judge it in it's current state. In my humble opinion, it now has been fixed to the point where more than just the die hard Total War fans can enjoy.  Combat on the battle map is enjoyable to watch, and difficult enough the personal skill and managing your troops can over come the odds. With the graphics turned way up you can sometimes find yourself zooming in to watch the almost cinematic mass combat in detail, realizing you should have been giving orders because you lost some troops to a cavalry charge behind your lines. The battle itself feels like the old Total War, but where most of the changes take place is on the campaign map. There, you can find changes in the old Total War formula, like managing provenances comprised of multiple cities making late game management more bearable. Most of these are welcome changes, and it's good to get a new slightly new spin on old mechanics.   Rome II is one of the best looking Total War games out to date, but you'd be either lucky or rich to have a machine capable of running it smoothly with high settings. There are still some graphical errors here and there, even when you turn everything way down. You can see they are still trying to work out some issues both visual and with the poor pathing for the A.I. but at least things have gotten better since release. My final gripe about the game is the unintuitive way of showing the tech tree and traits that your hero characters can take and how insignificant that some of those traits are. There are some that you just wouldn't choose and don't even make sense.  In the end, if you haven’t picked up this title yet and you are either a history buff or like strategy games it's worth giving it a try (or a second try if you jumped ship on release), but I would wait for a steam sale.

I still haven't quite figured out the happiness/order formula in the game, so every now and then I had a wave of slave revolts to contend with. The only critique I can give on it is that its just a larger campaign map for the Gaul area. The Roman Civil War is fun to play (shots out to Octavian), and overall its worth the buy when on sale.  All in all I'd rate IX/X  ROMA INVICTA

Great strategy game. Not often do games actually surpass their predecessors, however, this title certainly has, and continues to do so. The greatest strengh this game offers is it's replayability. The end game is a bit, incomplete, since I last played, however, this seems to have been remedied (think: Civil War's occurring - updates to the game have addressed this issue with notifiers and measures tracking the progress of potential upheaval).   I will add, I have never beaten this game, despite my many hours logged (estimated 600 hours), playing. This is how I prefer it. It is a great game to pickup where you can become engrossed in the gameplay and just veg. Additionally, you can pause your game and come back to it (save/load etc.) if matters of life take precedent. Very immersive historical journeys based on numerous cultures of the time. There are certainly con's I can write about but, overall, the game is a testament to strategy gaming history and I would highly encourage anybody interested in world history / anthropology / strategy / political science et al. subject matters to pick up this game, if not to engage in some aspect therein and obtain a different perspective.

In a few words, Total War: Rome 2 is, overall, a solid game.  *Purchasing the game during the Winter sale, I did not experience the major issues which plagued the launch of this game.*  Campaign is as a Total War game usually is. Its hugely enjoyable to conquer and ally with adjacent factions. I would therefore recommend it. However, there are some issues. Playing on 'Normal' mode during an entire Sparta playthrough, the campaign ai very rarely besieged any of my cities, if at all. Also, beyond maybe the 50th turn or so, if you have managed your cities to a reasonable standard, you will start to steamroll the other factions. Its far from game ruining to easily destroy factions & armies late game but if perhaps one or two other factions grew like I did, a hugely interesting war might have broken out.  Another grievance that I have is that defeated ai armies -which survive huge defeats with only a few men- return the very next turn with full stack mercenary armies. This often leads to the death of your previously victorious, but wounded, army in the city/lands that you just won. Especially during the early stages of a campaign. Again, not game ruining but these incidents put your faction and progress back considerably, as rebuilding takes time and money.  The game does look stunning though in my opinion. And the variety of units are generally well balanced. Cavalry beats swords, spears beats cavalry etc.   To conclude, Rome 2 is a good buy and a game that will keep you entertained for many hours. I would however reccomend that you purchase the game during a Steam Sale, like I did. This way, you can purchase the base game & all of the (ludicrous) DLC for around £40.   I do have some things that I feel should be addressed. Namely:  * Most ***PAID*** factions could do with having their rosters expanded. I paid good money to use them. Why should I be limited to how I can use their tools?   * Bring in the option to manually enter in a amount of $$ that is offered during negotiations. What if I dont want to offer $2000? Especially when $200 would do the trick.  * Siege path finding can be an issue at times. Notably when units are on walls.

Ok,   So i Pre ordered Rome 2 and i have to admit when it first came out the game was simply not ready for release. But now a few months later i have to say the whole game has gone from being a beta to a full working game.  Though they were wrong to release the game too early as i think it spoilt a great game for many of us. Me included. The game has only improved greatly with the addition of each patch.   The Good:  But now, thankfully its up and running how it should. With many varied armies, units, options and hours of gameplay. Its living up to its predecessors. Also the additon of steam workshop support has done wonders for the game and i would highly reccommend anyone who doesn't mod the game to take a look. As there are some brilliant mods that further enhance the game and make it even better.  The new army experience i feel is a great idea as it allows you to really turn an army into a specific fighting force allowing you to cater to any taste for any battlefield.  The new graphics really are amazing and allow you to view ancient battlefields like never before!   The Bad:  Magic powers and stupid capture points...   One huge disappointment with this game for me personally is the lack of a family tree as i feel this has massively reduced that immersive feeling that a more traditional total war gamer, like me, has come to expect. Seeing your family grow, have children, get married and have actually interesting traits. The new traits are awfully flawed and the fact you can only have a few further destroys immersion.  Generals now feel far too meaningless as they die after only a few turns and then can be replaced instantly. I remember having to work for hours to turn a general into a great leader and then when his death would inexorably arrive it would cause a blow to my army and me on a personal level after the time and effort i had invested in the individuel.   Overall i really like this game, i am a massive total war fan i have played since the original shogun demo was released many years ago! But i feel like there have been many great elements removed and many added that just take from what is a brilliant game.

Rotten from the very foundation. Even after 7 patches, (haven't tried the 8th) the following stuff remained true:  - There is no campaign AI. For the most part, all the AI factions do is make absurd demands of you, move their haphazard armies around aimlessly, and declare war on each other and not bother pursuing that war. They will NEVER declare war on you. You can have 8 full armies surrounding their capital and they still will not declare war.   - Battle AI is the absolute worst of any Total War game ever. You can find plenty of Youtube videos displaying the deranged idiocy of the game's battle AI, but the single worst offense I see and KEEP SEEING is the ♥♥♥♥ING FLAGS. In siege battles, there have always been flags you could capture to win the battle quickly, but the AI in this game is OBSESSED with the flags, to the point where they will rush PAST your army, NOT attacking, letting your troops kill them en masse without your side suffering any casualties, JUST SO THE AI will get at that ♥♥♥♥ing flag.  - Battles are a total waste of time. It takes a long while to load up huge battles, and due to the insane speed at which units move, kill, break and rout, huge battles consisting of 5,000 men or more almost always end in 10 minutes or less. For all the money that went into motion-capture for the units fighting, you almost never see any of it because the units don't ever bother holding formation, and end up cramming into one another in barely coherent blobs.   - Incredibly awful gameplay mechanics.  - 1 turn per year means your generals die of old age long before they even begin to become famous or notable. Every building adds tons of squalor, or takes tons of food. The only way to not have constant rebellions in your home province is to garrison every city with a full stack, or to NEVER upgrade your buildings past level 2, save for temples and farms.  - Worse, cities can only build 2-4 buildings in them, depending on their size. And since all cities are linked via the Province System in-game, an unhappy populace on the island of Crete can have your fabulously wealthy and well-provided for populace in Athens unhappy and on the brink of revolution. - No family trees, no families period. You no longer have any investment in named characters at all, much like Empire Total War. If your general dies, he's automatically replaced by a completely random nobody you've never seen before. You can't manage families or dynasties, and you may as well not even bother getting attached to any of them or boosting their skills since they'll die of old age.   I could go on but the list of its problems goes on so long. The state of the game now is literally one where there is nothing positive to be said beyond 'it looks pretty'

Heres what i think. It all adds up to a game that's utterly lacking in urgency or momentum. Yes, the woefully inefficient pace of Rome II after every single turn is the biggest culprit. But there aren't enough fair battles to break up the normal pacing, and those that happen aren't compelling. Developing provinces and economics feels more like tossing a dart at a board than counting down the turns until your shiny new building. The enemy artificial intelligence is practically pacifist, which is extremely odd for a game called “Total War.” Perhaps what's most dismaying about Total War: Rome II is that it doesn't seem salvageable—its problems are as much conceptual as they are pragmatic. I can't imagine a patch or expansion with a smaller map, even though that would be the biggest possible help the game could get. In most grand strategy games, the motivation to play “just one more turn” is the most appealing part. In Total War: Rome II, “just one more turn” is a threat. Rome 2 is a $60 early access beta. In their well-intended but poorly executed attempt at updating the Total War experience, Creative Assembly took great leaps backward with questionable game design and poor user interface compared to the recent Shogun 2.   It's painfully obvious that Creative Assembly and their SEGA overlord rushed this release. What's more despicable is that they thought they could get away with winging it by hyping the game with PR full-court press, rather than focusing their resources and already limited time on testing and refining the game. It saddens me to report that their ploy worked: buoyed by the overwhelming hype and the original Rome Total War's reputation/nostalgia, Rome 2 sold like hotcakes despite not being remotely close to living up to its true potential and being a worthy successor to the original Rome. And the truly depressing part is that despite being so disappointed and frustrated by this half-♥♥♥♥♥ release, I'd still play the ♥♥♥♥ out of the game... because at the end of the game, this is still Rome 2. Think of the game as a magnificently built palace, but filled with atrocious interior design and cut-rate furnishing. Hey, it's still an impressive palace from the outside, and the stuff inside you can fix on your own or get someone else to do it for you. Would you pass up on this palace? I didn't.  EDIT: Multiplayer Co-Op desync issue is STILL not fixed. This same problem has been in the past TW games... CA still can't figure out how to fix this.

Overall: 9.0 / 10.0 Gameplay: 8.5 / 10.0 Graphics: 9.5 / 10.0  + Amazing Graphics and Animations + Addicting Gameplay + Mods - some bugs + Extensive reworks/patching by CA   This game provides a challenging and exciting single player campaign, which is what I normally play Total War games for. It can be very addicting, and provides users with some variation in victory conditions based on faction, families/dynasty, and victory conditions (3 types for each faction). The game implements a 'politics system' which is used to provide you with short-term goals in order to establish your empire. Completing the goals provides a substantial financial boost, but othwerwise serves very little purpose. I would have liked to see a stronger focus on the specific characters in the diplomacy / politics section of the game. Currently, in the primary campaign you will find renown characters and generals such as Hannibal Barca, but they do not have any distinquishing features from any other general/character that would inspire you to use them besides their name. However, this criticism has been addressed by CA in the Ceasar in Gaul campaign which makes faction leaders unkillable and provides them with special abilities unique to the character. I'm hoping to see this appear in the Grand Campaign as well, but who knows.  There are also a fair number of mods released for the game, so if there is any small issue you have with the game you can easily check the workshop for changes, fixes, or extra content.   Many users complain about bugs and errors in the game. Personally, I have experienced very few bugs besides a few AI problems and occasionally experiencing issues with my GUI. But for the most part these problems can be fixed by reloading the campaign or they were addressed by CA in recent patches.   For users that already own the game, CA has actually given most of the DLC to users at no cost. Having pre-purchased the game, the only DLC I paid for was the Blood&Gore content. If you purchase the game now you will have to pay to purchase the latest DLC, but maybe wait to see how much you enjoy the game for yourself, before deciding to spend the extra eight dollars to play the extra factions.  Overall, my experience has been very positive. The game provides amazing visuals and exciting, addicting gameplay. I would recommend this game to anyone, especially to those who are already fans of the Total War games. Rome II is by far the most exciting and dynamic Total War game created. If you can put up with a few bugs here and there, this game is definitely worth purchasing.

7.5/10 'Fun, but not quite great fun yet!'  Ok so the game released with some issues, but through several patches many have been fixed. The game plays quite well and even isn't so bad on a lower-end pc, although it works significantly better on medium to high-end. It is fun to play and looks good, and despite there still being problems the support and communication from CA puts that of EA to complete shame. The game is relatively easy to mod and has a good modding community, also the new modding tools work well.   -This game could of done with a new engine but still works well. -It had a bad start but has been improved. -There are good updates and a good support team. -The modding is relatively easy and there is a good community. -Most importantly though, I find it fun to play.  -One big thing missing for me was the connection to the generals. I wanted a family tree, the ability to marry people properly, to let generals have children and get to name them. I wanted to make choices on how they grew up like in games like crusader kings 2, although not in as much depth. I then wanted events when they were older, more traits and a character I could make my own. Maybe I wanted too much, but instead I got boring pointless characters who seemed to make no difference and were basically expendable. If a modder could make this then the game could go up by a whole point for me. Of course not everyone wants this much so don't let it stop you buying this game. In fact this game can be fun so can be a good buy, but not everyone likes this kind of game so if your a previous total war player, this game may be somewhat disappointing but could still be fun. If your new to the series, watch some vids and see if you like the look of the game then make the decision.  Overall it has had a bad start but is constantly being improved (Unlike SimCity which is still bad). It is fun to play and I would definately recommend it.  So I give it a 7.5/10 since it could of been an 8 or even 9 for me, and may be given time, but isn't quite yet. It had potential but isn't there yet.  Also I want incendiary pigs. :D

Things to be noted -The AI is just as good, if not better than the other total war games, but nowhere near human. -The new province system is really is great, it adds much more strategy top the game. -The Roman era is the best :) -The modding community adds much more to the game allowing more hours of gameplay -As with all total war games, it is VERY replayable, due to everything being open to you. -The new abilities that can be used during battle are very good and add strategy to the game (also making it a little unrealistic) -The graphics, unit models and animations are much better than previous games so the battles look very cool to watch with the new cinematic camera which zooms the camera to the point of view of a unit (as if you are sitting on the shoulders of one of the men. It had a difficult birth, but thanks to various patches and the copious amount of excellent mods available on the Steam workshop it is now much better. Many people will moan about this game as being 'broken' but I for one have never had any real issue with it. People like to complain about a game for the sake of complaining but don't believe it. This game is more than worth the £30 (ninc dlc) and has given me (and continues to) many hours of fun.   There are issues with mechanics, I agree. It's far too easy for smaller, minor factions to instantly become huge because of the massive economy boost they get at the start of the game. It is however important to remember that this is not a historical simulator! If it was, you'd lose every campaign unless you play as Rome. The idea is to create a sandbox in a historical setting. This is something people like to forget, it is just a game, it's not a documentary.   I have never had an issue with battle mechanics, I've been playing it on Hard (not legendary though) since release and have found that this provides the best balance, The AI is beatable so long as you don't make a mistake but is capable of pulling off some decent manouvres. Sometimes the AI flounders a little, one thing I have noticed is that in a seige battle if you put ranged units on the enemies walls they will group their army right next to them, allowing you free reign to whittle them down with arrows, rocks etc. But it says more about the player than the game if you exploit this.   While some people don't like the way a land army can become a naval army, I find this feature perfect. In what way does it not make sense? Why bother to train a unit of hastati, and then place them on a boat when you already have a perfectly good unit of hastati that can just be placed on a boat whenever you need them to be. It is still absolutely worth investing in actual naval units because a heavy onager boat will destroy a transport ship in moments, so long as it is protected. At the moment it is admittedly too easy, it should cost a small amount of money to transfer onto boats (to cover the cost of building/purchasing the ships) for transports and it should also take 1 full turn to either embark or disembark, regardless of how many movement points an army or fleet has at the moment.  Diplomacy is somewhat broken, it goes from absurdly unfair in the beginning to becoming a cake walk within about 10 turns but again, it can be abused but only if you choose to abuse it.  Overall, excellent game - people need to stop moaning about it and try playing with a little restraint. The ones who hate the game the most are the ones who got bored, exploited it and then cry because their game was too easy and/or broken.  Peace.

I have no hope for Atilla, and not much more for the next Total War.

Overall, I'd recommend it to fans of the Total War series, and anyone who enjoys massive armies clashing in a hectic melee.

I have played all the other Total War games, right from the beginning with the original Shogun so I can say with some authority that this is the worst game in the series. The developers seem to have removed all the strategy elements from the series by 'streamilining' everything. Economics, diplomacy and religion are all gone now in favour of a more simple, arcade-style affair that treats the campaign map as little more than a visual representation of where the next battle will commence, never giving much thought as to why you have to fight that battle in the first place. And then, when you do get to the meat of game, the strategic battle mode, you will find sub-standard AI that struggles to come up with any strategy other than 'direct charge' or 'stand still and wait to get pummled' depending on whether the AI is attacking or defending. Sure, the game looks great but I don't buy a strategy game because I like nice graphics, I buy a strategy game because I like strategy, an element sadly lacking in this 'streamlined' point-and-click adventure. Rome 1 was a shining beacon of gaming excellence, a yard stick by which all other historical strategy games should be measured, and this game simply does not measure up.

Great game. Who ever played a part of the Total War series knows the concept: you build up your own empire in a turn-based strategy part at a world map. Whenever one of your armies or fleets enters combat, you take command in classical real-time strategy manner. And most important: Rome II offers you to do this in 2-players coop.  Imho the concept is great. In the strategy part you manage your provinces, build buildings, recruit your army and do diplomatic stuff with other nations. You need to make sure that your forces don’t have to fight at too many fronts at the same time, take care of your finances and decide where to reinforce your armed forces with which kind of unit. In tactical combat you command exactly the units that you brought to this battle. No wild reinforcement spamming or tower rushing like in other real-time strategy games. No artificial balancing. You have to fight out whatever situation your strategic decisions have lead to. Basic combat principle is rock-paper-scissors: cavalry beats melee infantry -> melee infantry beats spear infantry -> spear infantry beats cavalry. Of course there are different version of each unit type (light, medium, heavy), ranged units (javelin men, archers), artillery, siege weapons, ships and even special units like wardogs and elephants (really bad ♥♥♥...). And combat is influenced by a variety of other factors, e.g.: - attacks in the flank or rear of a unit are quite effective - units have a morale, and if it drops too low (e.g. due to effective enemy attacks, or other friendly units already fleeing) the unit might not follow your orders anymore and flee - units fight better in formation - weather (e.g. during rain you can’t use flammable arrows/javelins, during fog you can hardly see what’s going on at the battle field)  All in all the game is really fun. Not that difficult to understand, but hard to master.
This game is pretty damn good. I look forward for the Shogun series to take some of these advancements to its genre.

At this stage, this is the game it was meant to be. The Rome 2 we deserved. A whole year after it was released.  The battles are satisfying, tactical, and well paced. Fight animations and movements are superb, as if watching a battle from a blockbuster movie. Blobbing is non-existent (except for difficult pathfinding areas as expected). The arcade feel of the battles have been toned down significantly, with battles also lasting to the 20 minute mark at least, typically longer, on large battles.   The campaign is however still too easy even on hardest difficulties for the moderate player. A few hours in and you will be knocking over empire after empire. City development is interesting and lets you tailor each city economically and militarily to what would benefit you the most in relation to its surroundings and bonuses.  Graphics are just amazing. Optimization is no worse than any AAA title, however you will need a beefy PC to run decent frames on the max settings. Lower settings will work fine but you will miss out on a lot of exclusive animations and graphical features. Trust me, the difference between low and high are staggering. You will think you are playing a different game on each setting.  Glitches are few and rare. Co-op/online is stable.  There is no reason to skip over this game if you love huge, stunning, dynamic battles with a large variety of units and factions. Any lover of Total War will feel this is a good step in the right direction (at least on most features).  Don't worry about buying any DLCs though. They are a waste of money,

I had been waiting for this game since they announced it. I was super excited for what it could have been like. The hype and videos from CA made it sound even better. Being the total war fan I am, this game is good, and I do enjoy it. However, there are a lot of things that really turn me off about this game and would say it is not worth 60 dollars. At its current state post patch, its maybe worth 35-45 dollars at max in my opinion.  That out of the way, lets talk about the good things. The campaign map is phenominal, it is probably the best map they have ever done next to empires. There are a lot of tool tips and a lot of factions we all know and love. The graphics are slightly enhanced and the game loads up in a bout 45 seconds which is record time for any of who you know what I'm talking about. (total war games are notorious for booting up after 2-5 minutes) Over all the game play is pretty smooth and the campaign UI is improved.  Now for the bad things. Theres an enormous amount of reported bugs, grant it, it has just literally been released so CA will surly fix a lot of them. But that is no excuse for the carry over bugs such as campaign desyncing. That has occured since shogun 2, it was announced, they know about it, and yet it hasn't been fixed in shogun 2 and not even fixed in this one. So good luck playing campaign with your friends. The battle AI are even dumber then before, most of the time you can camp at your spawn and pelt them with artillery until they die or you run out of ammo. The multiplayer factions seem half done to me, they put so much stock and power into rome that a good roman player can pretty much take on anyone. Rome has almost 2 times if not more units then any other faction. After that it seems like they threw in some default models, varies the stats, then slapped the name of the faction on front of the model. I have bought all the Total War games since the origional Rome and enjoyed them all until this one, which will be the last one I buy.  While the bugs were legendary and have lead to a lot of bad reviews, even though most are sorted after an infinite number of updates, I still don't like the game. For me it has lost most of what made the whole TW series enjoyable and is a prime example of not following the maxim 'If it ain't broken don't fix it'. As with the other 'II' game versions I was expencting something that built on the origional game with better graphics, better AI, more depth, but CA seem to have thrown the bath as well as the baby out with the bath water.   The game seems more superficial, with the general's being far less interesting and their characteristics being mostly meaningless (I still don't know what they do). Only being able to have troops with a general is new and a major pain. Being able to sdend out small contingents to raid the opposition's territory or subdue restless natives is no longer possible and I like having Generals promoted from the ranks. The whole population unrest thing means your progress goes at a snail's pace as you have to sit your generals and their armies in towns for ages waiting for the locals to get happier.   The actual battles aren't great either, with the AI often being rather stupid. The opposition will quite often stand there while you destroy them with missile weapons or attack piecemeal and get chopped to bits. Also why the hell considering this covers the sclassical era as well can't they do a proper phalanx, because no matter how hard you try, once you attack, your Hopolites, who are supposed to fight shoulder to shoulder, start running around on their own. A ten foot spear is no good against a two foot sword in one to one combat!  Looking at the mainly negative reviews for the new Sparta DLC has made me realise that CA are now just out to rip off a very large and loyal fan base by releasing games far too early and then padding them out with DLCs that have increasingly less content. Except for the Blood & Gore packs, the Sparta DLC will be the first one I haven't bought.  My advice is if you want to play realistic battles and conquer the world without all the rubbish of having peasants chopping down trees and stuff, then buy any of the Total War games except this one!

With it's new exciting mechanics and graphical improvement, Rome II was destined to be (one of) the greatest strategy games of this generation. While not really being a bad game, as some metacritic rants would like you to believe, it certaintly didn't live up to it's expectations, and there are good reasons not to buy this game (or at least wait untill it's priced <$10 in the sales) - especially for TW veterans.  For NEWCOMERS to the series this game can actually be quite good at most times. The setting is (still) great, and the graphics are fantastic. One of the major downsides is the questionable AI, which sometimes does a fair job defending itself - certaintly at the harder difficulties - but more often than not just sends small armies to their death or makes just plain stupid decisions in battle.  Most of the new mechanics, like the provinces on the campaign map, are intresting and make Rome II a fresh experience compared to other entries in the series, but some of them just don't work. As an example I'll point out the 'flag capture machanic'. It's a great system to have for the siege battles, and makes a lot of sense, but in 'normal' field batlles, it doesn't make sense at all, and, more importantly, leads to bad gameplay. How are you supposed to set up for an attack if you're bound to a flag in the field which you can't move before the battle? That being said, battles are still the action packed eyecandy they used to be, though they tend to be much shorter than in most other TW games. If you're new and would like to give RTW2 a try, I DO RECOMMEND it, especially since most of the infamous bugs at launch are fixed due to patches.  For VETERANS of the series, who've been following the series at least from Medieval 2 or the original Rome, the game is much less attractive. Much of the problems outlined in the previous section (mediocre AI, random mechanics) are much harder to cope with for TW veterans than newcomers, so the chance may very well be you don't like it that much. Sure, there still are some nice and interesting touches made here and there, like the different victory conditions (campaign), the expanded campaign map, and the generally much better graphics, but for most longtime fans, the rest is only annoyance. The most noteworthy flaws are: AI still needs improvement, Battles are way to short, Campaigns are - even at higher levels - quite easy (a problem largely caused by the forementioned AI), some new mechanics don't work well at all, Campaign map is enlarged (it now bears much resemblance to some of the RTW1 mods) but somehow feels more empty, especially with the system of provinces. If you must you can still buy it, but chances are you will enjoy RTW1 even more than RTW2.  In summary:  -if you're not that much of a TW gamer and/or you're in for a fresh strategic experience you should buy this game -if you are a veteran of the series you might be better of skipping this entry in the series, or at least making sure you don't pay the full $50 for this mediocre sequel to rome 1. final verdict: 6,5/10

Grand strategy is where Rome II truly shines. The management of armies, provinces, trade, diplomacy, faction politics, spies (& champions & dignitaries), all combine to make the experience the closest imperial simulation I've yet played. If you think you would've made a better Caesar than Ceasar, this is the game to prove or refute your claim. There is no other contender.  The tactical experience is above par, and I found it entirely satisfying, when I've had the time and inclination to spend on tactical command of a battle. The nice thing about that is every battle can be resolved by the AI. You will almost inevitably do better if you choose to command your armies yourself, but when the odds are 3:1 in your favor, it's usually carrying coals to... well, to Nero's Rome, at that point. Granted, my most recent tactical command gaming experiences involve mostly games where the tactical experience is the equivalent of rock, paper, scissors on a pretty backdrop (ahem, looking at you Endless Space... so disappointing...) so YMMV.  The tactical (and strategic) user interface is simplistic (in a good way) and relatively easy to navigate for how complex this game becomes. tactical combat management is very similar to my remembered experiences playing Sid Meier's Gettysburg! It would help if the controls for fine-grained unit management were outlined more clearly in the tutorial, but a few moments searching the in-game encyclopedia's table of contents led me to the right section. I wish the tactical management system were a bit more refined, but the dizzying array of formations covers most out-in-the-open situations when battle does not occur in a settlement. It becomes more difficult to accurately place and orient units in closer spaces, but having served in the National Guard, I can assure you that real life isn't all that far from art in this case. All-in-all, having played the tutorial campaign and secured the entirety of the Italian peninsula as the Junii party in the Roman faction main campaign, I have no significant complaints regarding the tactical management.  If you like strategy gaming, love playing any CIV game (or Endless Space, Endless Legend, GalCiv, etc...) on a massive map, and like the ability to play a different game every time, this game is for you. The main campaign alone allows (even without DLC) you to play as widely ranged factions as the Iceni or the Seleucids and many more. The DLC nearly doubles the amount of playable factions, each having their own tailored victory conditions and inherent starting difficulty ratings. (Because of the complex nature of the game, it is difficult to estimate from one game to the next how the difficulty will vary, and I suspect my first game has become rather more difficult than it needed to be due to some early diplomatic blunders. Must remember to fire my foreign minister. Oh, wait, that's me...) In short, the designers of the game were clearly well aware of the Butterfly Effect, so don't make the mistake of assuming that the diplomatic game is as simple as bribing the people you like. Even that small action makes others change their views of you. This is no Civ diplomatic engine.  TL;DR - if you like grand strategy with decent but not overwhelming complexity, this is well worth your time.

Brace yourselves, ladies and gents.  Now, finally, over a year after release, Total War: Rome 2 is ready for public consumption. It's an occasion so momentous that Creative Assembly have commemorated it with a whole new edition, the aptly-named Emperor Edition. Presumably it means Emperor of the Botched Releases but to be fair, I haven't checked into this.  Before we get into the review proper, it's time for a history lesson more violent and terrible than the period the game in question seeks to recreate. It's 365 days ago. The dusty wasteland of the historical RTS genre languished under the yoke of an ageing Shogun (not literally), countless (not literally) of pretenders and hundreds (literally) of Medieval 2 Total War's barstard children via the modding community. The time had come for a new power to rise and that power was Rome. 2.  But then it came out. Like a sort of half-formed Nero it emerged groaning from the loins of Creative Assembly with twisted, deformed twin heads of pay-locked factions and flawed execution (probably not too far from those Nero actually ordered). This unpleasant image is no exaggeration, for much like the real Nero, Rome 2 persecuted Christians (incidentally, I'm sure - there were probably other denominations who purchased the game) by being one of the most buggy, poorly-executed major releases in recent memory.  The co-op multiplayer wouldn't work past turn 10. The AI - both battle and campaign - was awful, resulting in many siege victories via the 'kite-by-pleb' strategy, and the game ran atrociously even on top-end graphics cards. And of course, the game seemed as if it had been balanced by a mentally disadvantaged ape. How so, you ask? Well, suffice it to say that if the 300 Spartans of legend came up against a legion of my sharpshooting, machine gun-toting bog-standard slingers then they'd have been sent home upon their perforated shields much sooner than expected.  Needless to say, the Total War empire was in danger of crashing down like the titular (not rude) Roman variety. Which wasn't what anyone wanted. When it worked well, the game looked beautiful, it played well and the historical accuracy (and yes, you should care about it, because if you don't you're a pleb) had come on leaps and bounds. We wanted nothing more than to hoist Nero up on his shoulders and carry him about the place cheering, but we just couldn't. Because he was broken and a bit rubbish.  So then, fast forward to now and we see Total War: Rome 2 as it's meant to be. It's tight, well-balanced, runs silky-smooth and feels like a finished product. Those familiar with Total War games know what to expect by now and I'm reasonably certain (can never be 100% with gamers) you'll enjoy it.  For those new to the series, it's a game about rushing through all the boring campaign map bits just to get to the sumptuous and epic battles, most of which contain thousands of units at a time. You have a healthy number of factions to choose from (more if you have extra money to unlock them) and the feel of each one is unique. A number of factors can be instrumental to victory in battle, including terrain, deployable defences and how skilled your general is.  Actually, I take back the part about the campaign map, because it's actually a lot more dynamic this time around. Agents can be hired to grief the opposition in many exciting and annoying ways, from poisoning their armies (thereby reducing their numbers) to assassinating enemy generals (thereby making the opponent click a few boxes to choose a new one). Some would argue the AI exploits these way too much but I would argue back (and be correct) that they are now simply a vital component of your strategy and need to be used just as much as your armies. Keep up with your agents and they'll win wars for you, or at least stop your opponent's from winning his (wars) for him (your opponent).  Improving towns and cities does seem a tad limited - gone are the days of turning the sleepy hamlet of Piddleton into a megalithic super-city - but gone also are the days of trawling through construction notifications every turn. It's simpler, it's easier, it's more restrictive but less frivolous. Is it a good thing? That's up to you to decide (it is).  Diplomacy is also vastly improved over previous entries. How essential it is depends on your faction - Rome is generally able to slaughter everyone in their path till the late-game (as is appropriate) while a small Eastern or barbarian kingdom will likely have to forge and maintain alliances, even whole confederations to survive long enough to become a superpower. It feels quite organic, works logically most of the time and feels central enough to the gameplay to warrant a mention.  There's also a politics system in there but my lunch break's nearly over, so I can't say too much.  As it stands, Total War: Rome 2 - Emperor Edition is well worth recommending. You've been saved the post-release horror and get to enjoy the game in its intended form. Even if you don't want to help the economy (and Sega's poor starving children) and buy all the extra factions and mini-campaigns, there's more than enough to keep you busy for a while. If you see it for 60% off or more, I would couch it as an essential purchase.  Just don't go on any of CA's post-release bug forums - not even NASA build computers to handle that.

TW: Rome II is probably my favorite Total War game. Out of all of the Total War games I have played, Rome II is one of the easiest and most simple games (campaign-wise) of the series. For many people its simplicity is one of the problems, but it should actually be something to be attracted to in this game since it makes the game easier to learn.  The game lacks family tree management and certain elements found in earlier games which takes away from some of the experience, but it creates something wonderful instead. Total War: ATTILA was released after this, has more of the features from earlier games (with some removed that are in this game), and is much more difficult while still using the same map and principles found in Rome II. Because of this, Rome II serves as a good way to learn the basics before tackling TW:Attila or another game in the series. In many ways, it is better than Napoleon and Empire because the tactics used in those are much different than the rest of the series.  As for the DLC, most of the DLC for Rome 2 is overpriced and some of it should have been included at release. If there is a sale, you should consider getting DLCs that interest you as they do add more depth to the game. Some people may say that the factions included are the same as others or have too few units, but this is only partially correct. The Greek States pack (Athens, Sparta, Epirus) can/will play almost exactly like the included Hellenic factions (Macedon, Massalia, Baktria, etc.) but will not be totally identical with the most obvious differences being in how campaigns progress. If diversity between factions (DLC or not) is not enough, there are plenty of good mods to expand unit rosters and tweak the game.  Overall:  PROS: +Fun battles +Good campaigns +Good entry point to Total War series (ROME II is like TW: ATTILA with training wheels) +Diversity between factions/cultures +Steam workshop with many mods  CONS: -Expensive -DLC is overpriced -Lacks more in-depth features of other games in the series -Thermopylae was nerfed   9/10

Honestly, I don't like it as much as Shogun 2 as the direction in Rome 2 is kind of all over the place and without much motivation nor focus, could be a plus to you. Overall however I found Rome 2 to be pretty enjoyable though not nearly as polished as Shogun. My comparisions will be between these two as they are the most recent. My opinion may be invalidated due to the fact that I didn't play Rome 1 so I'm ready for your rage.   Of course what you want in a Total War game is here. Strategy, economy, city building, diplomacy etc. But everything just seems so barbones with corners cut and what was added doesnt feel good at all.   All of the hallmarks are here, tactics like flanking, hammer and anvil, elevation, ambushing, etc. Units are varied, can be faction specific and have unique looks from the different regions in the game, though most will say they are reskins. Unit type is also varied as most types will also have sub types and so on. An example would be Cavalry, there are subtypes like Shock Cavalry, Heavy Cavalry, and Light Cavalry that are used for a specific purpose, not using them for that purpose is somewhat wasteful. Naval combat is pretty good when it is working right, having the ability to embark land units on their own without naval specific units is a poor design decision however.  Now if you like quick tactics and have the attention span of a goldfish you will like the combat in this game. Battles end WAY to fast. Unit morale is the ♥♥♥♥ing worse I have seen in one of these games. I am one of those guys that like to zoom right in when the action starts but in Rome 2 by the time I zoom in one of the two units fighting rout. While I'm on the topic of zooming in why the ♥♥♥♥ does the camera level out if I zoom in/out? I want to stay at the angle my camera was facing thank you very much.   Anyways a usual fight will last you anywhere between 5-15 minutes, anything longer then that is due to either not engaging or waiting out the clock. To a newcomer this may still sound like a while but trust me 1/2 to 3/4 of the time is setting up your army properly and the remaining time is chasing down routing units. This part here is a big issue and ♥♥♥♥ing stupid design choice. So as in other Total War games your units can level up and the way to gain experience is by killing units, this means there is not a better time to gain experience then when the enemy is routing as they cannot attack back. Whoever decided to make it so that routing units arent shown on the map should be fired, you literally have to scour the map to find units to find the straglers.  You also cant field an army without having a general which leads to limited armies, no ability to garrison effectivly and frontlines that spread troops too thin. I hope this changes in future Total Wars.  On the topic of leveling up I think the system for leveling in Rome 2 is stupid, choosing what you want to level up is just a toss up as you dont know what you are working towards. In Shogun 2 the skill tree was set up so you could see what you could get and work towards how you wanted to build your general. Rome 2's Zeal, Cunning and Authority is a system that would be good if it was laid out properly akin to Shogun 2 but due to the fact that you dont know what the ♥♥♥♥ your skilling the general ends up being a jack of all trades and a master of none.  Competition in the early game is not too bad but it only gets easier, at around 5 villages you will probably be the biggest faction in the game and from then on is just a slaughter fest as you go for the 100% conquer. In Shogun 2 there would always be factions rivalling you in size and military strength the entire game. In Rome 2 once you get your first region everyone else just bends over and spreads their ♥♥♥ as you make them your ♥♥♥♥♥ by autoresolving and the once in a blue moon real-time battles.  UI is kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥, but I'm not smart enough to think of a way to fix it. I just feel like it could be more informative while showing less.  City building in this game is a ♥♥♥♥ing tragedy, there always this balance between unhappiness and happiness which has always been there but I dont understand why getting the best of a building would cause unhappiness, why are people upset when they get such a large amount of food, income, etc? I'm not sure if they have kept in the mechanic where you can just build one super happiness city in a region and just take a ♥♥♥♥ on the other villages and still be in the green but if they havent taken it out then this game is beyond help.   Money is never something you will have too little of, very easy to aquire and maintain upkeep if you are paying even the slightest bit of attention to the budget tabs.  Muliplayer works but that should'nt be praise worthy, it should be expected that things work. I also understand the reason they took out the avatar conquest in Rome 2 but I do wish that they could have kept the armor customization.  Game looks good but so does Ryse, gameplay is more important here. The action cam or whatever they call it is a nice addition and much better to look at than the first person they had in previous games. I wish we could move the camera around the unit though.  Diplomacy is paper thin usually only used to declare war or trade, alliances and what not are more for connon fodder and I do like the ability to walk over other factions territories without having to declare. Also seems like RNG to get a proposal accepted.  DLC is whatever, it's not going away. Thankfully some of them are more than a couple factions and units.  Lot of mods in workshop to cater to most of your needs and will add quite a while to the games life.  Not much else as I'm sure many other reviews have touched on thing more in depth then I have. The patches have brought the game to a pretty good state and if you wanted to ever try a Total War game then pick this one up and then buy the next one, that way it will look like such a huge step forward in the series to you.

This is an amazing game. If you have the correct hardware, its also a gorgeous one. I was initially skeptical of the mixed turn-based campaign and the real time battles, but it works well. Yes, there are some bugs in this game, more than any other Total War game out there right now, but this game introduces a great new depth while making the game simpler with the provincial governing system, along with being mostly historically accurate (at least at the start of the game, I have never seen Rome expand beyond Italy, but hey, they start with the right amount of territory). The only really negative thing I can say this game is that it is reeeeeally poorly suited for multiplayer. I mean, you thought Civ took a long time? This game is so much more in depth than civ, but that means that multiplayer games have the potential to last several days. The real time battles take up a ton of time, but in some ways, it is better than other games of this genre. Through this unique combat system, I've seen people lose battles they should have easily won, and others turn losing situations into ones where they emerge victorious. The game hinges on your abilities as a general, and that gives it an immensly personal feel. You get to say 'I just won that through my own skill,' instead of 'I had the better units so I won,' This is an amazing game, and although the $60 price tag is very high for a pc game, this game is one that is impossible to miss out on. Good luck conquering the ancient world!

If you are willing to ignore the unfulfilled hype, accept the fact that AI is actually worse than previous games, or that the game really has not changed at all since Shogun 2 and is basically a dumbed down, prettier version of Rome Total War, you can have a lot of fun with this title. It includes virtually all the features of the old games and can look splendid while doing it.

Having been a fan of TW since Rome I I was eagerly anticipating this second installment of the genre. Rome and Medieval II, whilst good in their day, look and feel dated now and Shogun II for me, was incredibly boring offering poor unit variety, and no replay value. I personally don't feel disappointed in the slightest. Yes there were a few slight issues at launch but every TW game suffers this. That doesn't make release problems right of course but you expect it from these titles. I never suffered with the FPS issues or the crashes but I understand that some did but credit where credit is due, CA have spent a lot of time building RII and patching it non-stop since release. With a few mods you can really get a lot from this title.  The graphics are the best yet (GEM mod helps also) and the combat animations are fluid and good to watch ( the blood & gore DLC is more realistic than the cartoon rubbish they added to Shogun II) and the campaign map looks great.  The political system needs some work though, I have not found any reason why its there at all and can play the game without using it which is sad. Since Rome and the Hellenic states were heavily political I feel, unless it's added later, was a missed oppertunity. The lack of family tree is superfluous as it did nothing anyway and has been missing since Empire (Shogun II had it but it may as well had not been) and I don't feel it's needed here. On the whole I really enjoy it. It has flaws yes but the game is still fun, looks good and has a lot of replayability. With Medieval II having not aged brilliantly this is the best place to get your melee fix.

Rome II starts off as a tough cookie. You always lose, even if you've become pretty good at Empire.  With enough experience, you can become good at it. And if you love total strategy and have some patience, it'll work out well for you.  Yes, there's no family tree. Yes, you can only have 16 armies max. Yes, public order seemingly becomes impossible to control if your empire is large enough. But, in all, due to the variety of patches, it's a great game. Replay value is 11/10 with the patches and emperor edition and some mods...  I recommend the 4TPY mod, all factions mod (xcept those that are designated as DLC only - well, I bought Ceasar in Gaul and the Greek States pack at my satisfaction with playing this game) and the balanced diplomacy mod and the ranged camera mod (so I can see my empire from afar); and finally, the ROME 1 music (it can't be beat) mod.  Also, it looks a bit cartoonish.  Rome II grows on you if you're in to the Total War games. It has become, over more than a year, a stellar game. I think that if it were relaeased today the metacritic score would be more like 85-92.  Battles are great (but make sure you have a decent computer). Loading is kind of long but quotes make it interesting. And of course, decisions decisions decisions. Do you want to upgrade your industry or prepare for a full-on war? It gets very technical so be prepared to lose for 50-200 turns until you master the 'glitches' or ways that you can succeed.  Attilla looks more like Rome II should've been. That said, it's still very compelling.  I would give it a solid 9.2/10, and 9.5 if you're into the material surroudning Rome.  Try to get it on sale! Pros: *Great graphics ,detailed models and variety of the soldiers characteristics. *It has some historical accuracy. Cons: *There are still bugs. *Most of the factions that belong to the same culture are more or less identical, they have just different colors instead of being unique in their own way. *Some factions have a lacking unit roster which may cause trouble if you want to expand your empire. *No family tree. This review i'm giving is for the modern version of this game, meaning no criticizing the HORRIBLE HORRIBLE release it came with.  Let's begin. ----------------------------   The game is set during the Roman Period, you are put into a faction that is scattered throughout the large and detailed campaign map. You as the player's job are to conquer, liberate, or starapay another faction to recieve bonuses such as money, XP, ect.  ----------------------------  -AI  The game's AI is I will rate it a 7/10. Depending on what difficulty you play on, the AI in this game can sometimes get twitchy but I recommend you just use mods to patch it up.  ----------------------------  -DLC  This game has given us loads of DLC's, some were utter crap and useles(COUGH COUGH BEASTS OF WAR, COUGH). And some were amazing(COUGH COUGH CAESAR IN GAUL, COUGH).  The DLC's in this game can feature new units, factions, and even MINI-Campaigns.  I was really hoping the campaign DLC's would just enlargen the Grand Campaign map making it even more zooming in, meaning instead of conquering let's say Scotland in this game, you would have to capture ALOT of cities to conquer it, not just one city.  I recommend the best DLC in this game is Hannibal at the Gates, I believe it is the most historic and hardest of them all, I disclude Caesar in Gaul because of it's technology, and we don't need to talk about that now do we.  ----------------------------  -Political Systems  The political systems in this game is I am rating a 4/10  Why is because this game fails to truly give the player a real experience as to running a Government. I played as the Roman Faction and all it says a person is, is a General or a Statesman. No no no, we do not want that, I wanted what Napoleon Total War had where you could host elections, fire and hire Consuls, Ministers, ect.  This game just doesn't mean my standards, because Rome I was amazing and I had HIGH HIGH HIGH expectations for a second version.  Now other than Hellenic or Latin. I consider Punic and the Southerns as Barbarian Governments, Councils, Chiefs, and Court Nobles I consider Barbaric.  The Barbaric Governments are just the same thing as the Latin and Hellenic, just with different titles.  ----------------------------  -Campaign(IN GENERAL)  The campaign itself is widely large, the entire map is just the Roman Empire, and your job is to re-conquer it as another faction.  The campaign holds cities and towns that you're allowed to Govern, you can wage taxes, put edicts to make it prosper, and build buildings of your choices.  The technology in this game allows you to unlock certain things in this game that given you benefits and advantages.  Each town and city holds public orders, I am COMPLETELY against the public order issues within this game because building a church can be a -20 on Public Order? That's almost hypocritical.  I rate the campaign itself a 7/10.  ----------------------------  -Battles  This game is what we came here for, the Total War it's made by. It's battles!  The battles in this game are fanominal in textures and graphics, it even features a cinematic camera allowing you to view a close up of soldiers fighting others in battle. Or when you play that Russian Hell March music and watch your soldiers marching in a city or field look like a boss.  The battle AI is not so fanominal, sometimes it can be utter idiotic, the AI itself still has not fixed itself from Rome II's horrible release date.  I rate the battles a 8/10.  ----------------------------  I believe I have covered the entire game on it's primaries, but this is just my opinion.  The final verdict for Creative Assembly's Total War Rome Two is a = 6-7/10  I know it's not reasonable to give it this verdict, but this game just didn't meet my standards, it has horrible AI, too long technologies, horrible public order system, horrible political system, and just bad DLC's that CA has coffed us up enough money from.  But in all honesty it's a 6/10 in my opinion, but to be reasonable it's a 7/10

A return to the old Roman Times was an outstanding idea. The developer had a tough task of beating a game that was based in the same period of time, a really well executed Rome Total War with it's add ons The Barbarian Invasion and Alexander. Total War: Rome II with it's new edition 'Emperor Edition' guarantees pretty graphics, realistic battlefields, realism in governing your Empire. The game is really fun, replicates really well the tension of those days, when Roman Empire just managed to beat Carthaginians, and their path towards becoming what they are famous for. Emperor Edition also adds a new campaign, based on Roman Civil War between Octavian, Antony, and Lepidus. You can choose whichever 3 of those factions (Octavian's Faction based in Italy and Gaul (France), Antony's Faction based in Greece, Turkey and Middle Easy and Lepidus' Faction based in Hispania (Spain) and Carthage (Tunisia). You can also choose various 'barbaric' factions such as Egypt, Armenia, Parthia (Iraq) etc.   However what hurts this game is the amount of DLC's. They should have included most of those DLC's (such as Hannibal, based in years before the start of the original campaign, or Caesar based just before events of Emperor Edition's campaign). Lack of the Historical Battles is also a problem. Rome Total War had many more Historical Battles to enjoy.   To conclude:   Strong Points:  + Good graphics  + Beautifully executed, replicates tension of Ancient Times  + Realism in battles (fighting animations are outstanding)  + Beautiful Campaign Map   Weak Points:  - DLC content that should be added as a patch for a bad release  - Release state was pethetic (it is fixed now but still it's not something to be proud of)  - Lack of content on Historical Battles  - Could do with more playable factions   Score: 7/10

Rome II has - in general recieved a lot of negative reviews. But I find it a refreshing game. It's a step away from the old style of gameplay, which was good as well, and a step in the direction I think Total War should be going towards in the future. It provides far greater immersion thanks to it's integrated battles, it allows larger armies to take to the field, and it gives you a real sense of the destruction and chaos that held sway in Roman times.  If there's one thing I would like to see make a come-back, it would be the generals' speeches. They set the tone for the coming battle, and gave you a vigour and purpose in fighting the battle, made you believe that the men could win, even if the odds were stacked against them. If I could suggest something to change to the general's speeches, it would be a greater integration depending on the General's personality. A high dread general would tend to deliver speeches that spoke more of what would happen to the soldiers' families if they failed, about how the enemy is weak and to show no mercy... that kind of stuff. Whilst a general tending towards the paragon side, would deliver speecher geared more on building up his soldiers' moral. He might talk about how he trusts them,how they are the best in the world, how their families are waiting for them back at home, stuff like that.  It is never a bad idea to improve the campaign AI, but I hardly found it as lacking as most described it, and the latest patches have cleared up most of the kinks still in there.  All-in-all I found Rome II to be a worthy edition to the Total War saga, a game that's immersive and comprehensive. It has enough detail to make you think, but isn't so complex that you feel overwhelmed, as one sometimes does with games like Civilization. It's blending of TBS campaign play, and RTS battles, is unique and still ground-breaking, even today. Total War is a franchise that I admire and the only one that I follow fervently. The designers, coders, artists etc. that worked on the franchise through the years have my greatest respect and my humblest support.  I can't wait to see where the franchise will go next, but what ever they decide to do, I know it'll be a game worth playing, and an even greater edition to the Total War series.  The Total War franchise is known for it's historical quotes, and so, pray forgive me for ending my review with one of my own favourite quotes.  'Leaders think and talk about the solutions. Followers think and talk about the porblems.' ~ Brian Tracy

The graphics also kept increasing to further heights which made watchin the battles close-up immensly fun. Now to the harder part. I have to be honest and say I've only spent a few minutes in the game and even less in a battle, and the reason for this, is that the game infuriates me to such degrees that I couldnt keep playing. First off is the horrible, horrible UI, I've never been so annoyed in my life. The last games were easy to navigate and control. Everything from your armies to your cities. Suddenly instead of having an overview of the map the screen is just crammed with smaller windows with ugly pictures of your general and HUGE unit icons. Then theres the city management which they screwed up big time. Instead of having cities in provinces, you know have provinces with cities. This might sound like a good idea, but when your enemy or other AI, can have a few cities in the province, then you start becoming really confused. Furthermore the building options have been extremely limited of what I can see. Now that's out of the way, let's continue to the most disappointing feature in the game. The combat. Again it's the UI that lets the whole thing down. In Shogun 2 you had 3 simple features to look after. Minimap, Unit Management and Unit List. It was so nice and simple. In this Rome II abomination you have the same 3 features only they've scaled up the Unit List and and removed the unit management from the lefthand bottom corner to under the unit list. So you have this big mother ♥♥♥♥in box filling up the screen where the fighting is happening. Then theres a useless picture of the general or whatever ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you got controlled in the lefthand bottom corner. In the olden games, you atleast had the nice army control button. I remember them fondly from Shogun 2, so when you had your whole army selected you could move them forward, whilst they stayed in formation. Where are these controls now?! I couldnt find the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ things and tried moving the whole army forwards, which resulted in just a long line of crap. The minimap they also placed down in the bottom line, just in the righthand corner. WHY DID YOU DO THIS? Now there's a huge line of windows in the bottom of your screen, which is also where all the fighting and unit movement goes on. Why not move some of does ♥♥♥♥♥♥ windows up in the tophand corners in the sky. I'm interested in the ♥♥♥♥in battle with swords and death and blood, not a load of UI windows! Furthermore that bloody unitlist and the new unit icons is bloody awful. It's the most simple thing I have ever seen, I can't understand they wanted to do the whole Roman/Greek culture with tile/marble kind of style, but the units look so bloody similar I cant see the difference between a general and a standard unit. The bloody sequel to Creative Assembly's popular Rome: Total War, Rome II offers a few new ways to play with your units. Instead of just hovering over them like a helicopter mom, why not give a unit a morale boost by hovering over a unit with the Cinematic Camera? With the Blood and Gore expansion, you can now have decapitations and amputations! Doctoral Warfare has never been so much fun! Well, unless you were fighting actual doctors... It would be quite boring. I mean, they'll just throw vaccines and pills at you whilst you cut them down with gladiators or naked warriors.  Although the launch of Rome 2 was shaky if not downright terrible, after several patches it is playable. There are three major issues that I want to point out: 1: Paid DLC for Factions; Although the recent Imperator Augustus FLC came out around ten days ago, the fact of the matter is that some people (myself included) would rather unlock factions through beating them to a bloody pulp rather than having to pay for a number of factions (Shogun 2 suffered from this). However, the Blood and Gore pack and the Daughter's of Mars pack are $3.00, so not all is lost considering these packs were actually worth it. Plus the Imperator Augustus FLC gives you Armenia, so that's a plus. 2: No Family Trees; Although I personally don't care that there is no family tree, I'm still writing about it. Just like Empire: Total War, there is no family tree. However, UNLIKE Empire: Total War, it's hard to know who your replacement leader will be unless you know how ancient cultures worked. This is especially true of the Barbarian Factions, such as the Arverni, where a complex political structure meant that the heir to chieftom could be booted out (as was the case with Vercingetorix). 3: Lack of Voice Variance: Although there are several voices for commanders and soldiers alike, this is in terms of the accents. For example, I'm fine with the default Barbarian voice, but only for the Gauls. When it comes to the Brythonic (British) Tribes, one would expect to hear native accents (if you listen to Welsh, Irish or Scottish Gaelige, or Manx, there is the British/Irish/Scottish accent). When it comes to the Germanic Tribes, one would expect to hear a more gutteral accent. And then you have the Etruscan League.... Sometimes voices just do not fit.  But other than those issues, the game is excellent. If you can look past the paid DLC, lack of Family Trees, and lack of accents, this game is amazing.

The first Total War title I ever played was Total War Rome, and I loved it. So, of course when I decided to get Rome 2, I had extremely high expectations. It did not disappoint, although it was different. Luckily I avoided the myraid of glitches that were inherited with the game when it first came out, I bought it a year later for $20. And let me say, they have more than fixed the glitches.   THE GOOD This game looks beautiful on any decent machine, and is runnable and still looks good on underpowered computers (I have seen it run on lackluster laptops). The gameplay is immersive and very in depth. I find myself spending hours into this game at a time, trying to negotiate traties with factions I wish to destroy at some point, but for now provide a good border that I wish to use as the backbone of my empire. Yet at the time, I am building up my cities to provide better units, rake in money, and most importantly, keep my people happy.   Also, the battles are better than ever. For those who don't know, the overall game is a turn based strategy, and then when you fight battles you can choose to auto resolve (for quick results, but higher losses and lower chances of winning), or to fight the battle on the battle map. Here, you can control each unit (up to 20 per army) and choose different strategies yourself. This is very engaging and dynamic, although I do like to set a time limit of 40 minutes or else you may find yourself in a situation where there is one hidden unit that you cannot find and it takes 50 minutes to end the battle! Anyway, the battles are the best aspect of the game and are very engaging.  And I can't forget to mention online campaigns, they are just extremely fun. If you have friends with this game, you will love the online coop campaign or the head to head!  Last but not least, this game has a great replay value. I have loved playing every faction I have tried (except Parthia, they literally have no good infantry). Each faction offers its own great units, buildings, locations, and strategies. I do recommned buying DLC however, because some of the more fun factions (such as any Greek faction, which I adimit, is annoying) is a faction you must buy. Also when you replay, trying different difficulites is fun. Playing this game on easy is a good challenge for someone new to the game, but way too easy for someone experienced. I find that the way to have the most fun is to challenge yourself!  THE BAD  The cost of the dlc. Plain and simple, this game is not cheap and the dlc is no cheaper. I DEFINITELY reccommend waiting for a sale to buy this game and its dlc; every dlc I have bought (which is everyone except 4 smaller ones) has been on sale. And I can say, on sale the dlc is fairly priced. And although the game is probably worth 60 dollars, if you wait long enough you can probably get it cheaper.   There are still some glitches, although only two major ones I have seen. One is that the function to move around the map will suddenly stop, for the rest of your campaign. This is very annoying, because now you have to double click the map to move anywhere, and sometimes your viewing angle will change, which you also cant change back. So you're looking at the map upside down and can barely move the camera around. It sucks. In my experience this happens more in online campagins. The other glitch is that sometimes during coop campaigns one player will just be dropped. Although this is annoying, it is a normal bug for all games and will likely be there forever. Also, since the game saves at the end of every turn automatically, it is not a big deal with losing save data.  THE CONCLUSION  Buy the game! On sale! WIth friends! It is definitely worth it. I love this game and do not listen to the reviews about the game breaking glitches, they have been fixed!

Total War Rome 2 is without a doubt the worst game in the series, maybe on par with Empire. Thankfully however this isn't saying too much as it is a pretty decent strategy game. It's definitely still not worth 60 dollars. To cut the review short, I'll do the standard pro/con list most people do.  Pros:  + When the AI or other units don't bug out battles can be immensely fun. + Multiplayer campaign and multiplayer battles are very fun with friends, although public games are few and relatively boring. + Graphics are very good, but still not as good as Shogun 2. + Units are very diverse and different cultures have different tactics (Romans depend on raw discipline and heavy infantry, Carthaginians are flexible using different soldiers from different cultures, Celts and Germanics use the very shock and fear of a powerful charge, etc.) + New province/region system is better than what we had with Empire and Napoleon. + Modding community is very good.  Cons:  - AI is very stupid in battles and are very incompetent when managing an empire. - Looking at soldiers fight is very boring and poorly presented (They often flick off into the air and spin around when getting poked in the ♥♥♥♥, etc.) - DLC Campaigns are very uninteresting with the exception of the Greek DLC and the free one with Emperor Edition. - Many, Many Faction pack DLC's and other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. - Despite what the major Review companies say the 'Super epic Rome 2 cavalry charges!' is nothing more than Celtic Riders running over the first line of soldiers and then slapping at the poor ♥♥♥♥ers below before getting shoved off their horse by a shield. - Too many factions that have little to no different besides faction bonuses. There are really only about 5 different unit rosters. - Most special units are just things like oathsworn (Celts with chainmail, a sword, and oval shield) and greek hoplites with pretty shields and shiny helmets. - Tech tree is pretty standard and boring. - Often times the major nations like Rome get taken over by Etruscans or some miniscule Celtic tribe. - Naval battles are pointless, boring, hard to command and this is where the AI bugs out the most. - I know this isn't really a negative spot on gameplay but the majority of the budget went to bribing IGN and making 'Super early pre-alpha footage' look nice. Just look at the Carthage siege 'pre-alpha' video and then watch release footage and you will see what I mean. - Hard to run without a high-end computer. - AI really bad at sieges and there are only about 1 walled city in every region or so, making most assaults boring.

The Good: I've been playing the Total War series since the original Shogun came out fifteen years ago, I've played every incarnation except Attila, and I have to say the series just keeps getting better and better. Rome II definitely has the feel of a massive campaign, with massive armies and massive empires battling against each other. I've only racked up 20 hours as of writing this review but I can see that this is one that's going to eat into a lot of my time.  Graphically, it's a very beautiful game. Unfortunately my system won't run it on anything approaching ultra settings, though even on a mix of High and Very High it still looks heaps better than (for example) Medieval 2 on its highest settings. I know I'm going to need a system upgrade at some point in the not too distant future, but for now it looks like CA have done a decent job of optimising this game for lower-end systems. (For those who need to know, I tried running the benchmark on Ultra settings across the board and got <5 fps. o.O)  Having said all that, as with most games, there are bad points to this one as well as good.  The Bad: As a few other reviewers have said, this is one of those situations where you buy the base game, and can have a lot of fun with it, but to really get the most out of it you have to then buy a literal metiric f**k-ton of DLCs. The core game is thirty quid, and then all of the DLC is another sixty quid on top of that, and this is a good year or so after the game was released. Now, I appreciate that game developers have to make their money, and I don't have anything against DLC in particular, but I think three new campaigns (at a tenner each), four new culture packs (at six quid each), two new unit packs (at two quid each) and the blood and gore add-on (also two quid) is maybe going at bit far?  And The Rest: I love this series, and despite my whining over the cost of all the DLC I will probably end up buying it all at some point. I'll also end up getting Attila (plus all the DLC), as well as Warhammer (plus DLC) when that comes out. I'd like to hope that somewhere along the way CA and their publishers make a few changes to their business model as far as DLC is concerned, but I'm not going to hold my breath. I also hope that the series continues to push the envelope on what can be achieved graphically and technically with the games. As long as they keep doing that, I'll keep playing 'em.
