First the bad, then the good.  -No family tree. This just sucks. It's a feature I've been in love with since Medieval II, but is gone here. Sad, but true.  -AI is a little... funky? Usually it's pretty intelligent, but it will do stupid stuff like walking to the middle of the other side of -the map and staying there if you've occupied a corner of a map and are unseen. Your army wins at the end of 20 minutes of staring at a timer, but there's no combat. -There's no 6x speed. Some of the maps you'll play with more infantry and war machines than others. 3x is nice, but it's insanely slow if the other guy is waiting on his reinforcing hoplites to walk the map. -Repetitive general traits and ancillaries and traditions. While I love the army traditions, there are some severe limitations in the type of bonuses that one can give to an army. (Hoplite centric traditions for factions like Massilia that have a large spread of Gallic troops as well as Greek. Makes it awkward when only one kid's getting the proverbial lollipop.) I fell in love with the Medieval II sprawling lists of hundreds of traits and bajillions of retainers. Your leaders had character. They also had families. But I digress. -DLC packs are often screw jobs. The Greek States culture pack should have been included in the original game, and I'm frankly rather disappointed in the 'new' campaigns that are attached to the game. All of them are essentially the same game on a smaller map with dynamics and mechanics that are relatively unchanged. The variety is... lacking from what one would hope.  The goods -Da Mods doh! The mods that are available for this game make things GREAT. More unit variety, more interesting looking units, total changes in how the mechanics play out, whatever. It's all there. -Huge maps. They're gorgeous and just too much fun.  -Naval battles are far better than any of the previous TW titles IMO. Just IMO.  -Lots of faction variety. 'Nuff said. -Mercenary system. This beats the crap out of M2's system. No question. -Diplomacy. Useful options! AI is sometimes quite funky on this as well, but it is actually helpful now. -Unit appearances. Most are pretty good looking straight out, and I play on relatively low visual settings. -Traditions for armies. This is just brilliant and tremendous fun. Armies have flavor that didn't exist previously. -Beating Romans and the Arverni as Massilia, beating the Thracians up as Sparta, shooting enough arrows to fuel the sun as Parthia.  I'd absolutely recommend it, especially if you're one who's open to using mods. (Look up Sir Eggmond, Cataph, Champloo, and Sebidee. They do some of the best unit mods)

I know I was and still am to a certain extent. Its like people who play pokemon Gen 1 Fire red and Leaf green and they play the new ones and say it is trash because of the nastalgic tendancies. So I think everyone is being a little critical. However I also paid for the game after it is has been patched a lot and for 11 bucks on sale, so I can understand if someone bought the DLC and the game at full price after seeing all the glitches the AI and gameplay on youtube from the past and even some now, that they would be frustrated because this was supposed to the be the biggest total war game. But for me it was worth 11 bucks actually more, so I would say wait for it to go on sale, its not worth 60 bucks, its good but not that good. Dont get me wrong Sega did a decent job, but I think they kind of swindled people who bought it at release. But the game is fun, the DLC just isnt worth it.   The gameplay is extremely different from the other games. For instance, the spies and champions are extremely powerful and can deal enough damage over time to basically annhialte a full stack. Also there are garison armies which can actually fend off a legit army if used properly. The biggest thing for me that is a downfall but cool as well is the fact that there are SOOO many factions, over 100, literally. Every turn for basically the first 100 turns you will discover a new faction, which is realistic I guess but its also very, well complicated. Declaring war on someone may result in an enemy tribal confederation or 4 factions declaring war on you. Oh the politcs thing is cool I dont have to send a politic to their gates to engage in politics. However, the politics system for you important characters such as inherators or faction leaders and their political rivals, makes NO sense. You can literally have a civil war which is a nightmare, out of NOWHERE. The civil war bar may not even be full at all and you will have a civil war or it could be up very high and it will never happen. It can happen at 90 percent of the gravitas or 40 percent, its confusing.   Finally the actual warfare. The warfare is waaaaay more involved. Flanking and using units special abilites affect the battle much more than in previous games. For instance a pike phalanx if its flanks are protected can literally take out an entire army no matter how strong(excluding missile units), whereas in M2TW it was practically useless. The battles actually arent simply determined by troop quality(never was completely but it is less so in this game, in my opinion, feel free to comment, no harsh words though, just trying to give insight), now you can destroy an army with lesser soldiers if used properly, that was harder to do in M2TW(Please keep in mind I have only played and seen Rome 1 and M2Tw). I would say it is more involved. The amount of units a card can have is more so instead of 60 being in a stack now 120 can be which is cool!   Concerning the map, units automatically heal themselve in your own territory so you dont have to retrain them. Also you can set your forces in 3 stances which is forced march which forces them to march farther on the map but get ambushed, the forticifaction which is for an army that builds a defensive mini fortress to make it difficult to kill them all of and some other stance which makes them ambus other armies, I actually dont understand that one haha. Also ship battles can be fought personally. The most ANNOYING but also cool addition to the map is the provinces, basically the map is split into many different provinces and if you share the province with a rival faction than it affects your settlments as well. This is EXTREMEMLY annoying if they have a seperate culture because the clashing cultures in the province will cause rebellion. If the whole province isnt under one culture one or both cultures suffer and it gives more incentive to conquer the whole province. Now this is realistic and causes you to have to manage the cities in more strategic way so it is more challenging. Instead of simply spreading out into a box or whatever way you want to, your empire will be shaped into the shape of the provinces.   Overall the game is more deep and I think TW players are to used to not getting this involved in the game, it is almost too involving. They are used to simply training high quality troops and sending them to clash and steam rolling. It requires more strategy. I do recommend this game, it is fun, maybe not at release but it is now.

530 hours later, here's my thoughts:  The Grand Campaign does its job moderately well, but it is a bit lackluster in comparison to the previous Total War titles. For instance, the AI's more incompetent that ever, which surprises me considering CE boasted of having a larger budget and would feature improved AI for Rome 2. Family trees are also removed, the Roman Senate's nearly non-existent, you can't change your capital, and just a lot of details like that are missing. The mods in the Steam Workshop can be spectacular though, adding some much-needed substance.   The Augustus Campaign to Rome 2 is like what Barbarian Invasion was to Rome 1; it's a solid addition with some improvements here and there. Although it feels a bit emotionless and the AI's still a mixed bag, I had a blast playing as each Roman party. People may not find it as gripping if they haven't seen HBO's Rome (OR just aren't familiar with the politics of the time).  Can't comment on the other expansions or multiplayer though, as I haven't partaken in them. What I can briefly comment on is co-op campaigns. Aside from the occasional lag and crash, I can't really complain about it. The hard part is finding someone who's willing to invest a chunk of time into it with you. Haven't played Shogun 2 co-op in a while, but friends say that Rome's co-op feels a lot slower, as you can't manage anything on the campaign map once you have ended your turn.  All-in-all, I recommend the game, especially if your computer can handle it on high graphics settings.

Based on the following, how likely are you to recommend this game to a friend?  Highly likely - likely - neutral - unlikely - strongly unlikely.  I'd say right between neutral and likely.   Overall, it's good. The RTS battles are just as good, if not a little better, than Shogun 2. And since most people pick up TW games for the RTS battles, it needs to be acknowledged that the land battles are pretty good. I just wish that the unit cards were better, I really don't like the art style as I have a hard time distinguishing among the different unit types. There are mods out there that change the unit card art, but I don't think a mod should have been needed for this.  The biggest drawback imo is the campaign map. And this is true of Attila as well.  I feel that there are a bunch of things in the campaign mode that are there stictly so that there's something new/different for you to manage. Now you have to manage population, population growth, and family/government influence. Unlike previous TW games where your population was really only something that reflected how much money you could get from taxes, in Rome 2 you need population numbers to actually build stuff. So you might need 4 population tokens to build that new building you want. It's almost like CA just started adding elements that you needed to manage just so they could say the campaign mode is different. Some people like these things; but as someone who's been playing these games for years I honestly just think it's a little annoying and makes the campaign map mode more clunky.  *1. Buy this game on sale. There's a lot of content that is just not included in the base game, and buying all of the additional content to complete the game is honestly just not worth it. Check steam and humble bundle frequently. This game is a few years old, so wait for it to go on sale. there will be a sale, just wait for it.  *2. Buy this game once you have played Shogun 2. I think the AI is more difficult, and the overall game is just more solid. I'm not saying Rome 2 isn't worth buying, but Shogun 2 exists and you should probably give it a go before jumping on this.

UPDATE: The review below was from long ago, and it just doesn't do this game and it's community of players justice to not come back and update it. I eventually acquired all the DLC's on sale, and I have to say they all the different campaigns complement each other beautifully. The grand campaign for me takes a bit of tweaking and modding to find the perfect mix but can lead to one hell of an adventure once you find it (thanks to all the brilliant modders for really keeping the enthusiam alive for this game after an underwhelming launch, which pushed CA to continue polishing on thier end). Also, I have become a huge fan of Historical video series that have been created using this game, it is a testament to how much this game can offer. I tried at one point and maybe will come back to it at some day. Once I build my new PC I plan on getting into multiplayer battles, which I never experienced, and put my tactical expertise to the test (or get wrecked). CA can never get enough credit for allowing someone like me who had watched Gladiator 10 times before I was even a teenager to experience these massive, hellacious battles from the ancient world in stunning detail. To another 20 years of Total War. END OF UPDATE   The previous Rome and Mediaval 2 have set the bar extremely high and I was very excited to see the latest installment to the series. I understand there have been other entries in Total War series since those two gems, but the smaller map of Shogun and the newer technology available in Empire put them in seperate categories in my opinion. The presentation is top notch as usual and really brings you into the time period. Rome 2 tries a number of different things and while some are great ideas that are definite improvements over the previous titles, others are a little dissapointing.   A list of the good changes/improvements from Rome and Medieval: *Settlements now have garrisons, and different buildings will generate specific troops that will defend the city. *Agents have more available actions and can enhace armies and settlements in different ways, and also hinder the enemy. *All characters (agents, generals, admirals) can be upgraded in whatever areas you choose. *Armies and navies carry traditions, and while the troops may be destroyed the traditions can be reinstated. (This is defenitly one of my favorite features of the game.) *Allies can be given war targets to conduct a joint attack. *Armies and Navies operate together and you can launch awesome naval invasions and deliver your troops right to the enemie's gate.  And now some of the new features that are not quite improvements but still have potential: *While it is more realistic that only generals can lead armies outside of settlements, it also prohibits you from combining forces and the limit on the amount of generals you can have slows the game down. (Admirals and navies work the same way.) *Holding slaves is a good idea but they don't seem to benefit you in any way and instead simply revolt against you again and again until you realize to stop enslaving your defeated foes. *The abilities that units have on the battlefield do provide an advantage but it also leads to micro-managing as your constantly activating them and then waiting for the cooldown. Once again good concept but not good execution. *Only capitals have wall defenses, the other villages cannot be fortified which doesn't make much sense. *The politics system seems useless and not nearly as engaging as it strives to be. Alot of work can be done in this area. *At some point Rome will become divided and a civil war will break out, but there should be more factors that lead up to it and affect it's outcome.  I admire CA for trying new things but the diplomacy and politics seems a bit stripped down from Rome 1 and Medieval, and it becomes a bit repetitive. Constantly fighting slave revolts and losing settlements because they can't be fortified becomes frustrating. The battles are thrilling, but the enemy A.I., espicially when you are under siege, is so predictable that you'll be able to win no matter the odds. Most of these issues are just minor annoyances, but its the performance issues that have turned away many Total War fans. Thankfully those of us who have been patient have seen a much improved game, either from updates or fan-made fixes. The fact is that for $60 you would expect more from the developers of such a great series, and I am still shocked at how CA expects us to pay even more just to play as factions that should have been in the game to begin with, like Sparta and Athens. I refuse to pay for the DLC campaigns unless they offer some major improvements to the base game.   All in all, this is a great game and even at full price I can recommend it to strategy and history enthusiasts, and as usual the large amount of mods can offer significant improvements to features you dislike, so try them out until you find the perfect match for you. 8.5/10

Horribly shallow. Many of the criticisms leveled at this game are to do with the technical bugs. My bigest bug-bear however is the lack of soul in this game. The original game drank a minimum of a hundred hours of my life with its depth in the game mechanics. This game will entertain you for an hour, maybe two..... but the mechanics are soo limmiting.  Allow me to extrapolate; 1) the new city and province system means less cities, less tactical positioning (due to the renforcement system), faster conquest meaning you can steam-roll your opponants in a very short time. 2) the new familliy and polictical features might as well be absent because they pretty much are, they have little if no depth and very little effect. You never get attached to characters so you cant even invest in the personal story and devlopment of a character and his familly. Also- no family tree. 3) In battle game mechanics are at best inconveniant and at worst downright breaking the game (admittedly they have apparently patched this since). 4) Buiness model..... breaking off parts of the game to sell as paid dlc or pre-order bonus'. I sadly paid for a pre-order for factions which are already in the game. This is a practice that really needs to stop- dlc is meant to ENHANCE your experiance, not steal from it. This is just pure greed and very consumer unfriendly. 5) Lackluster design. The game looks horrendous on anything but a top-tier machine. It actually looks worse than its 10-year old predecessor. The designs are generic and disinteresting with a horrible art-style to boot. A poorly optimised source engine also meant that even when playing this with a computer well over the minimum specc, and being forced to play it on low/medium, it stutters with a framerate of 5 frames per second in the 'cut scenes'.  In all- a heartbreaking mess for anybody who loved their previous games. Be warned- this is an avoid and if you are really desperate to play this than Id say its not worth anything over £10.

I want to recommend it. I REALLY want to recommend it. But I just can't.  This game is incomplete. It's been out for months, and is still incomplete. The AI is littered full of bugs, the between turn 'other faction' time is still ridiculous, and the units have been diminished.  Skirmishers in Rome 1 would carry two spears. Now, they carry roughly thirty each. Though this has made them significantly more useful, it's not realistic in the slightest. Further, and much to everyone's dismay, the God forsaken 'Flaming Sticks of Death' are still present. Attacking some walls? No siege equipment? No worries, just throw some sticks at their gates and burn them down in seconds. That's unrealistic enough, but you carry on the assault after that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, you'll find the gates have an infinite amount of boiling oil in a nigh neverending stream of death. 5000 legions dead in 2 minutes flat. I guess that balances them out, but why they couldn't have forced you to make siege equipment AND limited oil instead is beyond me.  But that's just you attacking. Defending, you might as well just put your feet up. I've successfully defending against 10,000 angry gaul with just a few hundred dagger wielding untrained plebs. Why? Because the AI doesn't understand sieges. In fact, it becomes ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at the first second of a siege. They actually patched it so that the AI can spawn with ladders to attack your walls, rather than simply blindly charging with Flaming Sticks of Death every time, but all that's changed is they now push the ladders to your wall before thinking '♥♥♥♥ climbing that ♥♥♥♥' and begin throwing Flaming Sticks of Death at your gates.   Oh, and the patches broke War Dogs. My favourite unit, which mowed down enemies, but for some reason glitched when the handlers were the other side of a settlement's walls to the dogs which could cause a game crashing bug. They patched it, and instead, the handlers now CHASE AFTER the dogs to engage the enemy too! I don't know how they can actually break something more in a patch.  The list goes on and on, many of the bugs are niggly little things (for example, siege weapons will 90% of the time reposition after ordering to attack someone, even though they already could perfectly well hit it).   I enjoy playing Rome. But it's too broken, and abusable. I've only got as far as I have in my game due to the broken AI, and it's unavoidable to encounter the broken AI. It's fun in the beginning, and many of the bugs are ignorable, but after just 10 turns it becomes blindingly obvious that this game is neither complete, fixed, or enjoyable in the long term. And the icing on the cake? It's not even realistic.  Final thought: They did add a patch which introduced the revolutionary mechanic that formation units will try and stay in formation. Shame that after so long, testudo is still broken, so raising your shield above your head actually increases the missile damage you take.

Total War Rome 2 is the latest in Creative Assembly's long time franchise and is one of mixed feelings. On one side many things have been improved like the Campaign U.I making it easier to manage settlements, armies and navies. The setting is perfect, it feels as if the Roman period is THE period for stratergy gaming, But the release of Rome 2 was shameful. Massive bugs, pathetic A.I and barebones features. After several patches the game is starting to take shape but it shouldn't of needed to as CA should have delieved on the hopes and expectations this game created. I personally think Rome 2 after it's patches is very enjoyable for both veteran Total War gamers, newcomers and general history lovers. I recommend this game to anyone interested in stratergy games and now that it is on the Steam sale, definatly pick this one up. The game consists of turn based campaign and real time battles. On the campaign map you build up your settlements, creating buildings to achieve various pursuits. Recruit troops for your armies and navies. Engage in diplomacy with other factions to form alliances and trade agreements. Use your agents to foil the enemy, train your soldiers and improve the happiness of your people. Real time battles are immensly fun and give you a sense of awe. Hundreds of Roman legionaries crossing swords with barabarians or Spartan Hoplites going head on towards some African Elephants. It is a sight to behold. Mulitplayer campaigns are fun when you get them to work,most of the time you will de-sync which is very annoying and frustrating. Multiplayer battles are the only other form of multiplayer which is a shame as Shogun 2 (Rome 2's predecessor) had customizable armies and generals, a campaign mode called avatar conquest, it is a shame to see this feature go. If you can look past some of the issues such as barebones features and occasional A.I issues, Rome 2 is a game you can invest hundreds of hours of gameplay into. A fun and interesting stratergy game, Rome 2 at present gets a 7/10.
You really can't compare it with the 1st Rome, but it isn't better or worse. Just different and awesome in it's own way.

I, like many other TW stalwarts, bought RTW2 on release day (in my case a retail copy). As some may have heard: reactions were... strong. It is a sad fact that CA released what was clearly an unfinished game (I do not blame CA however as it seems more likely that SEGA were responsible - I cling to the hope that it was another case of business execs, knowing nothing about games, pressuring the developer to release the game ahead of schedule even as the team cried out for more time (it's EA, Bioware and Mass Effect 3 all over again!)). I however, was one of the few lucky ones who had no serious graphical/loading or indeed any problems at launch (in fact I was able to run Rome 2 on higher settings than I ever had Shogun 2 and still have a stable game - something that the many patches released since has reversed). So when I was so blessed as to play the game without obstruction what did I find?  A pretty solid game to be honest. Though the AI was not the best I had ever encountered I never experienced any of the horror stories of enemies charging towards my lines only to turn and bolt at the last second (there were also naval battle issues but as I auto-resolve all naval battles anyway this did not trouble me in the slightest). The AI in battle seemed to me no better or worse than in Shogun 2. Campaign AI was another story. Suicidal armies attacking well defended settlements with 1 or 2 units, AI moving their armies to nonsensical locations and making absurd demands in diplomacy. Check, check and check. But to CA's credit the patches released have improved these issues considerably. Graphics by contrast is the mirror image of AI. At launch I was stunned not only by the quality of the graphics but the fact that I could run them on middle-high settings without a significant frame-rate loss on my Windows 8 Dell Inspiron 15R laptop (yes I play my PC games on a laptop laugh it up). Mutant faces and blurry textures were only a problem when I zoomed out from my beloved legionaries. Sadly that is only a memory now as patches inteded to fix the problems that plagued the majority of players seem to have reduced the graphics quality I enjoyed at launch (quite why this is I am at a loss to fathom). But graphics have never been a major concern of mine and I am not very skilled at the TW series (poor AI on easy settings can give me a run for my money on a 'good' day) so perhaps I am not best qualified to judge the game on these aspects. What about the features?  One complaint that I often hear about RTW2 is the lack of family trees in the campaign. This complaint (I feel) is based on a lack of understanding. Roman patrician families were not 'royal dynasties' like in Medieval Europe but were more akin to Mafia families. Not all patricians aligned with say the Julia would be related by blood or marriage but instead are bound by employment, friendship and debt. Thus a family tree would be of little use in laying out relations within a faction. However this structure would not apply to more hereditary factions so the failure to include a family tree for non-Roman factions is a failure on CA's part. As for the capture points. I hate them (at least when they occur in small settlements and open field battles). Diplomacy is a bit of a mixed bag. On the one hand there are now some interesting options and it can serve a purpose beyond extorting money and establishing trade (marking war targets is helpful). On the other hand some older features missing that should have been included such as territory trading and being able to specify the exact value you pay/demand from another faction (as things stand if you want to bribe a faction into helping you in some way then an absolute minimum payment is enforced based on your faction's total wealth - this is pretty annoying when you are a highly prosperous state dealing with a measly minor faction and have to offer them double their entire treasury to get them to agree to a non-aggression pact - can't we haggle?). The main feature which annoyed me was the 1-turn=1-year system. Quite apart from ridding the game of discenable seasons it also means that generals and agents never develop as they die of old age before making a mark on the world. This means that only incredibly long lived or active characters ever recieve the higher upgrades. Fortunately a number of mods are available on the workshop to tweak this to many degrees (I personally recommend the 24 Turns Per Year mod (1-turn=2-weeks)).  Some will have noticed by now that I am somewhat forgiving of the fact that patches and mods are needed to improve this game. Note well that I am not pleased about that! I would much rather that CA had released to us the game we had been promised. The one shown in demonstrations. But it would seem that SEGA are the guilty party in denying us this. As a publisher SEGA naturally have no real talent but profit from the talent of the studios they publish. To SEGA CA making a TW game is not an exciting prospect for the same reasons as it is for us. We look forward to a new game in a great series. SEGA see an oppurtunity to make more money. Thus they encourage hype and release games early to maximise their profits. The problem with this of course is that the game then fails to meet expectations. Hopefully, SEGA will learn from the disaster that was the RTW2 launch and allow CA more creative control in future (note 'hopefully' - we have no idea just how stupid the guys at SEGA are but repitition (or not) will tell). But as for Rome 2 itself? It's a decent game, much maligned and haunted by it's stumbling first steps into the light of day. But it is my own fervent hope that the patches (a sad necessity) released by CA will eventully bring Rome 2 up to the level of game we hoped for.  7/10

I have mixed feelings towards this game.  On the one hand, it's a good game. As far as turn-based strategy games go, it is a good game. There are a lot of cool aspects to this game if you're a first timer. The conversations the soldiers have between themselves is a nice touch (although forced in my opinion). And the battle sequences are entertaining (to start off with).   However quite quickly you get over the the pointless frills of the game and you get into the grit of it. As a huge fan of this game since Rome: Total War I am absolutely livid with the progress. The Grand Campaign makes no sense to me. So many buildings have negative effects on your campaign (i guess to promote balance). Generals will fight two or three battles before they die of natural causes so you will never really develop a general into a scary ♥♥♥ mutha f***** (which used to be one of my favourite aspects of the game). There is no family tree (which is also one of the most annoying aspects of the game). And the inner faction conflicts make absolutely zero sense and have zero visible effects on the game. Also irregardless what you do in the game you face WHAT IS THE MOST ANNOYING PART OF THIS GAME is 'civil war'. When I say it is the most mindless addition to the game I am not understating it. I have crushed the civil war twice in two seperate campaigns but it is just an annoyance. Nothing else. You would never say, 'oh yeah, that's a cool addition. That makes everything really interesting'. Instead you will be left cursing constantly at your sheer disappointment and quit at the first sign of those banners.  Unfortunately, this seems like the path that the Total War series has decided to take. In Shogun 2 it was the same thing, where all of the factions would turn against you and just begin an onslaught. As all series do, Total War seems to be losing it's way a bit. Medieval 2/Rome was still the best game Total War game to date, simply because everything was awesome in it and I never stopped dropping my jaw.  Anyway, because there is no neutral button I would have to say No, do not purchase this game.

A significant change of process for Total War: Generals are raised per region rather than per city. This imposes an economy on your forces -- you don't spend them easily. Pros:  Amazing Atmosphere Amazing Maps Amazing Sound Design Amazing Animation Great Graphics Great Music Surprisingly Immersive Relatively Historically Accurate Combat Mechanics consistent with the series Great game for Total War players (like myself)  Consistently being updated with bug fixes  Cons:  TERRIBLE AI Very disappointing multiplayer Vs.  Extremely slow multiplayer Campaign load times Graphical Glitches for a majority of players Unit Power Balance Issues More taken from the franchise then added As with the rest of the franchise, long loading time is present Bulky UI   Immersion is known as one of the most important aspects of gaming, a game designed around making YOU feel like you're playing the character, or a general moving armies is very important part of gaming. Immersion can be achieved with graphics, sound, and realistic map styles. Rome II gave me the immersion feeling, I felt, in all honesty, like a bad ♥♥♥ general. The sound design, graphics and animation played a very heavy part of this. For those people who think that RTS, TBS, or similar games cannot give immersion, I invite you to try Rome II.  Unfortunately, the game falls short on far too many issues. The AI for the game is poorly designed, to the point where even the newer players will notice. Either they make terrible decisions, or just stand there.. and never move. Waiting for the player to attack.   The multiplayer is by far my most disappointed aspect. It goes without saying, a great multiplayer will keep a game alive. Conversely a multiplayer without features is an easy way for players to lose interest in the game. I really hope they add more features to the multiplayer soon.  I am very impressed with the attention the game is currently receiving from its support staff, and the programmers that are consistantly releasing updates. If they keep this up, the game will keep going strong. Either way though, you only get to make a first impression once, I'm sure they know that, and so do the hardcore fans. Rather disappointing.   Either way, I would recommend this game for anyone who loves either RTS games, or history buffs. For newer players, I recommend it a couple months down the line, wait until they fix all of the resounding issues.

'Is it worth it?' Yes. Absolutely.  'At full price?' Yes.   I've always been a huge Total War fan and I can honestly say that this game is my all time favorite. Although it certainly wasn't when it first came out. I was one of the few people who could actually play the game from the beginning since I have a fairly powerful gaming rig and I was absolutely disappointed. I tried with all my strength to love Rome 2 from day 1 but I just couldnt bring myself to enjoy it. So, like so many others, I left it. And I waited for CA to fix it. They most certainly did.   Now, I won't say that the vanilla product, even now, is a perfect game because it isnt. But if you get certain mods(i.e. Divide et Impera, any of Radious' stuff), which take no effort to install, this game quickly becomes one of the best strategy games out there in terms of gameplay, history, replayability, and just simple fun.   I HIGHLY recommend this game (with mods) to anyone who loves strategy and Roman history. You will not be disappointed.  PROS: +Great unit variety in bigger factions (all factions have awesome unit variety with mods) +AI offers a fairly good challenge  +You will truly feel like you are fighting real wars with real mens lives at stake, especially in the mods. +Army traditions/leveling up generals add a great incentive to keep armies alive and make each battle a little more tense. +Very easy to get totally immersed in the game and lose hours to it.  CONS: -Barbarian unit variety (without mods) is poor.  -Sometimes you can feel too overpowered as a player, especially when playing as Rome -Seiges are VASTLY improved from how they used to be but they still aren't that great.  -UI sucks  Neutral: +/- Most battles are won as soon as you turn the enemys flank. This makes complete sense and is ALWAYS satisfying, but things can get repetitive occasionally. Especially when fighting a series of small battles. +/- Some factions that should be powerful can get wiped out very early game (i.e. Carthage, Athens, Sparta, Rome). I can best describe this as disappointing. Because all the fantisies of having Legionaries pitted against Spartan Hoplites can get stomped out very early on in the campaign. Although this isnt a bad thing because it leads to very interesting diplomacy and wars later in the game.    Bottom Line: Total War: Rome II without mods: 7.5/10  Total War: Rome II WITH mods: 9.5/10

This is an update to my November 2013 review.   As of patch 14, and the moding community in full swing, this game is among the best in Total War history. There are many cultures who play different from another culture, so it won't be the same playthrough time after time like it was in Shogun 2. The siege AI had a major overhaul in patch 14, and no longer uses torches most of the time, and will instead opt to use siege engines, and even reuse them. The battle AI is among the best in the game, far superior to Shogun 2's AI where it will not only flank, but it will also attack your rear if you are not careful. I myself once got caught off guard by battling two armies, and instead of them combining like they did in previous games, one went around me and attacked my rear catching me by complete surprise. The province system, once you get use to it is great as you don't have to hover over the particular city to upgrade either it, or the buildings in it. You can also dictate a number of edicts, which at the moment is not all that great as they have no advirse side effect to them. The polticial system is still in need of some serious work, but it is better than it was at launch. The overall system stability is far better than it was at launch, as I no longer have any chrashes, and most of the glaring bugs are fixed.   Overall, this is a really great game, and worth every dollar. Just a heads up though, it is not as pretty as Shogun 2, but this game has far more soul to it than Shogun 2 does in terms of faction uniqueness. Also, before anyone asks, no there is no family tree.

The game started off pretty badly, so much so that I entered into a re-fund battle with EA. However since then it's alot better. Point being the Devs have definatly fixed probably 80% of all my complaints (I didn't go into all of them on my negative review, I could have gone on for a while..) which is great. With the release of the Emperor Edition, which included the free campaign pack 'Imperator Augustus', Rome II is a much improved beast from the dark days of it's launch.  - General battle speeds have been reduced, allowing more time for the player to either attempt tactical maneuvre or simply enjoy the spectacle. - Performance has been significantly improved across the board. The AI, in campaign and battle, has had many bugs ironed out. - Of particular note are siege battles, where there is now a legitimate challenge. - On the campaign gameplay, the building and politics systems were extensively overhauled, although politics does still suffer from a certain level of unresponsiveness and inexplicable behaviour.  This is still a different experience from previous titles, but one thoroughly worth giving a shot. If you're still on the fence then there are Let's Plays aplenty on Youtube.  ****Original Review****  Graphically impressive. Excellent combat animations and sound effects. Streamlined empire management. That's the good stuff.  The campaign itself has the depth of a puddle. The much vaunted politics system is pathetic. Diplomacy and CAI in general is broken. Essentially, you'll be doing exactly the same thing 250 turns in as you were 20 turns in.  Battles are ridiculously fast. Units are horribly balanced. Plenty of features and controls are broken or poorly redesigned. Voice work is mostly poor. 90% of battles are sieges and siege battles are currently broken.  All in all, an extremely poor addition to the Total War series that suffers as much from bad design choices as it does from a lack of optimization and extensive technical issues.

Okay, So I've finally got around to playing this game at length...My docket was full so I'm nearly two years late in writing a rewiew for this game. But, as they say, better late than never. So..here goes:  On the whole, I would say buy this game, on sale or no. I think it's worth the money. There has been no small amount of controversy over the bugs and unfortuneately, i think that has put many people that owuld have otherwise enjoyed this game, but instead decided to forgoe buying it all together. For those that did not buy the game, you've missed out. From what I can tell the bugs have largely been addressed and rectified, and the correction of these bugs (I never noticed them. I never had one problem with the game. I still don't know what everyone was talking about. I started to suspect that people were playing this game on a PC or Laptop that simply did not have the chops to play and truly enjoy this game at its full potential. And therein lies the rub. If you have a low end PC or a laptop that did not cost you about 1100 bucks to purchase, chances are you will be very miffed. This is a VERY high end game. And when you experience the cinematic view during a battle, you will understand why. While there has been every effort made to make this game agreeable to lower end PCs, you are doind yourself a disservice if you do nto have a newer model video card designed for PC gaming with it's own onboard RAM, and enough RAM otherwise to choke a yak to play this. I know it's not the be alll and end all of computer graphics, but for Total War, their battle engine and it's cinematic mode are beautiful to behold and are singular in the TW Franchise. If you DO have a good high end machine, buy this game, and when you are following your unit of Hastati through the woods, point your mouse so you look, so you can see the light filitering down through the leaves, and tell me tthat the sight is not beautiful. Not only that, but it tends to put you into the game on a level that was simply not present in the previous installments of Total War. The DLC for this game is outstanding, and the MODing community is very active.     As far as the things that I think CA might have dropped the ball on, I would have to say that getting rid of the family tree, along with the traits of a ruler that you could mouse over in previous TW games was a mistake. The way characters were set up before, it was much easier to, at a glance, discern their personality. I always though that the Devs of the Series had done well for themselves when they created that previous aspect of the game. Lets see, what else....Oh, the Encyclopedia leaves a good deal to be desired, the unit tiles, more specificly, the artwork they use, was a poor choice. I know what they were going for therre, but I don't like it, but there is no accounting for tasste and that shouldn't affect any one's decisions to purchase this game. Finally, the Political system needs a complete overhall. I like the idea of it. It's a good concept, but too little effort was spent in fleshing the political system out, and this is reflected by the the players complete and utter lakc of careing whether or not their factioin leader character has enough Gravitas. The Faction leaders seem....boring, and lifeless with no real reason to root for them, or sing happily when they finally die. From what I have been made to understand, the new game, Attilla, which comes out on the seventh of Fedbuary, will, at least (and hopefully much more) address this aspect of the game with the reintroduction of family trees. I get the feeling that Atilla will evetually far outshadow Rome II as the better of the two games.   Would I reccomend this game? Only if your PC has the chops to play it. I give the game a solid....8.0 of of 10

I swear, I tried really hard to like this game. I really wanted to. I don't like it when people put on rose-tinted glasses to declare that so-and-so old game is better than its sequel, and I especially don't like hyperbolic declarations that a game is broken or unplayable. So from the outset I was rooting for it to be not broken and terrible like all the haters are saying.  But.... here's the thing. That's what Rome II feels like. Kind of incomplete and poorly thought-out.  Rome II has a lot of attractive window dressing. The campaign map looks gorgeous, there's a lot of authentic flavour especially that feels like a big improvement over the first game, and I really like the streamlined menu interface - being able to jump right back into your campaign from the launcher for example is great.  But all this window dressing conceal core mechanics that are kind of a mess. The battles are a confusing slog - in ten hours I almost never felt like my skill on the battle map made any difference whatsoever to the outcome of the battle. I get what they're going for with the classical-style unit cards, but they don't do a good job of telling me what is going on at a glance. Likewise with the units themselves - while they look fantastic up close, it is often hard to distinguish units from one another until I zoom all the way down. Naval battles are outright broken. Ships often just stop responding in the middle of a battle. I had a close naval battle that just ground to a halt as the AI apparently also switched off, and the combatants just floated awkwardly at the edge of the battle map until the timer ran out.  The campaign seems to have a lot of potential, but it's full of oblique mechanics that the tutorial prologue and the advice pop-ups don't seem to ever explain. How much negative public order is bad? Why does it take years for a Roman army to march up the length of Italy? What's the deal with slaves?  R2:TW gets a lot of flak for being super buggy on release. This, along with the 'Emperor Edition' label, implies that it is a good game now that the release-day bugs have been ironed out. In my opinion this isn't the case. It's conceptually interesting and pretty to look at, but at its core it just isn't  fun . For this reason I find it hard to recommend.

***I made this post on total war center. I believe it fits as an updated review as well!***  I don't think that battle nor campaign map AI deserves such high praise considering that battle AI does barely more than flanking with 2-3 units on both sides while running straight into center with the rest. I like that AI uses CAV to attack my rear and that it apparently focuses on pike units with its range but that is really all that it got which isn't in all seriousness a whole lot to write home about in my opinion. CA should watch more youtube multiplayer tournaments to get an idea of what is possible when we talk strategy & tactics. For example, splitting an army into two to attack from two sides instead of only focusing center would force - no matter what - the player to react to it. I mean, R2's battle AI is so unimaginative that my favourite game during battle is to beat my casualty record instead of wondering if I had a chance to win or not. They are also always using the same army composition which makes different approaches during battles for AI even harder. The only difference here make those horse archer factions but that's about it...  Campaign map AI frequently declares war on me for no reason, even when way weaker or far away. The only explanation I can come up with to justify their behavior for myself is that another faction probably paid them to do so. A positive thing is that the AI indeed uses agents to cleverly stun one of my armies to attack my second one with superior numbers. A negative point is that AI constantly gets ambushed by my armies due to the fact that it simply has no clue how and when to use 'forced march'. It constantly loses entire armies by sending them over the sea without any protection while the game mechanics, on the other hand, allow it to attach one army to a fleet for protected sea transport. Allies conquer settlements just to lose it one turn later against bigger numbers right next to the settlement and without using other available forces in the immediate area. That behavior forced me more than once to stop my advance to clean up the mess which the AI had caused. Allied AI wastes its forces by taking over settlements which are way too far away from their reign of power just to lose it one turn later instead of concentrating on targets which they're actually able to hold and reach.   There are still a ton of bugs which are admittedly not game breaking anymore but still annoying (see list below). Naval combat, on the other hand, desperately needs fixing. Vessels occasionally get pushed around as if the hand of a divine being was pushing them. AI can use magnetic powers to board vessels. AI can use a second ship to support an ongoing boarding battle while it's impossible for me to do the same. A very awkward situation is when you defend a coastal settlement against an attack from the sea. Such maps only offer a restricted amount of spots to land on, once this amount depletes every other unit of the attacker will just wait on sea without anything happening. This is especially very frustrating when you decide to play without battle timer. Therefore, you either give up or wait until the timer runs out!  I play on legendary and got about 500 hours of R2.   My main problem with R2 at this point besides buggy naval combat is that the whole thing simply turned way too fast into one of those 'shut off your brain and do the same thing over and over again' games almost as bland as fetch quests in MMOs. Instead of streamlining CA should rather take a look at overly complex paradox games like EU4 or CiV5.   The more options AI and player have, the longer players can enjoy the game instead of streamlined boredom...  List of bugs which are still present and annoy me: 1. Forts which are covered in hills. Happens in Wrath of Sparta campaign DLC. You've to attack a fortified AI army in the area between Larisa and Pharsalos. 2. Character portraits which get stuck half-way during the process of popping up so that only their foreheads are visible in vanilla and Wrath of Sparta campaign DLC.  3. Arrow towers which are impossible to be taken over in Wrath of Sparta campaign DLC. I cannot remember anymore on which siege map exactly this bug occurred.  4. Diplomacy and other buttons which are randomly greyed out in vanilla and WoS DLC. You've to fix that by opening another screen like politics (where you can see influence etc). 5. Army signs/emblems which randomly disappear on campaign map in vanilla and WoS DLC. Army emblems will become invisible on campaign map. I think it has to do with reinstating armies but I'm not sure.  6. Factions where way too many generals have the same name in WoS DLC and very rarely in vanilla, too. As Athens, I had once the name Pericles spead over three different parties 5 times at the same time!! 7. When you click too fast between leader portraits on the diplomacy screen, the next leader will finish the sentence of the guy before him with full lib synchronisation! Happens in vanilla and WoS. 8. Sometimes, especially during turns the faction flags of armies turn black several times in vanilla and WoS DLC.  9. During battles units shout randomly their name even when you do not even own this type of unit but fight it! Happend in vanilla and WoS DLC.  [edited 04.02.15]

At launch, this game was a complete cluster**** with horrible performance, completely unplayable, and tacked on mechanics to make up for shortcomings (infantry throw torches because the AI was completely incapable of using siege weapons initially).  Seven months, and ten major patches later, most the worst aspects have been fixed. The game seems to be stable, is enjoyable to play, and for the most part the AI can do it's thing now (although those idiotic torches remain). Four turns to per year and seasons have been officially added to the game. BUT  Complex family trees are still missing. Diplomacy is still spotty. Agents are kinda 'meh'. Graphics are mostly good but still has weird texture issues with peoples' faces and is not at all as it was advertised. Still has stupid redistribution of territories (for example Carthage owns only a tiny part of its territory, as does Seleucia, with the rest being 'affiliates' that in my case at least, declare war on me within the first two or three turns). Vanilla is very arcadey with MOBA-like powers and battles are over WAY too fast.  In summary, the game is 'fair to good' but far from 'great'. I do not recommend playing it without a bevy of mods, particularly Lines of Battle, which dramatically alters the combat making it much more tactical and thoughtful.

I think that the Total War Series was right to Choose Rome 2 as the next Total War Game, I've been an enthusiastic Total War fan since Medieval Total War 1. I Loved Rome 1 Total War, and Have played over 1,000 hours. I played the rest of the Total War games and really enjoyed them, especially Medieval 2, and Shogun 2.   That being said, I tried to like Rome 2 Total War... I tried so hard, and couldn't. The Game is terribly broken. I pray that someday it is fixed and fun to play. To be fair I haven't played Rome 2 after the first few months it was released, and many (but not all) little glitches have been fixed since then, but the things that ruined the game for me have not, to my knowledge been, nor will be, fixed. I have only played 12 hours at this point, and I am know that the game has improved since I played it.  First of all The Army/General system is dumb! No longer can you send some units to hold a bridge, or split your forces to accomplish multiple goals. You can't lure enemy forces out of fortresses, nor can you deplete the armies to that their cities are weakly defended. YOU CAN ONLY MARCH A FEW ARMIES AT A TIME,!!!!  '......why???'    Construction in cities is so dumb I don't have time to talk about it. Instead let me role play, 'Ahhh I have my great city, with tens of thousands of people, time to choose what to build, oh look I get a hand full of options to choose between, hmmmm dock, or stable or inn hmmmmmm. WHY CAN'T A CITY HAVE ALL OF THEM? what real city says, oh I'm sorry you've filled all six-eight building slots, we can't build any more. The building and city management seems so dumbed down it is not only uninteresting, but frustratingly limiting. Also I shouldn't have to choose between two buildings to decide what defense is SPAWNED to protect the city! To see an intelligent model for comparison observe the way it is done in Rome 1.  Also Why can't you build city walls? how is it a siege without walls? baahhh  My review is that I love that creative studios made this game, I just wish they had made it well. I dreampt about this game for years. When it was released this game dashed my faith in Total War and the direction it is taking. I've gone back to Rome 1 and medieval 2 because they are much better games. I also really enjoy Shogun, because even though they had started to mess up building management, the game still contained soo much genius, art and strategy that it was a blast.  I plan to Check in on Rome 2 every year or so, hoping that either through patches, mods, or a combination of the two, this game can become a worthy sequel to Rome 1.

The game looks great, the gameplay is fun, has to be the greatest title of the genre. In comparison with Rome 1 it took a while to get used to having a very limited number of armies to conquer and defend with (3 to start with and 16 at the end). This made it more important to make tactical use of these armies. Each race is so different that it makes for an entirely different experience when you swap to a new one. To top that each faction within a race has different sets of bonuses, allowing you to put focus on their strenghts and play like no other faction can. Starting a grand campaign with a friend is awesome. I wasnt arround when the game was riddled with bugs (or so I hear) but it works rather flawlessly for me, just remember to save at least once every ten turns in Co-op, as an autosave may be corrupt and you wouldnt want to lose the progress to a 2 player grand campaign.
